job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
This is a first rate university with very intelligent researchers, professors, etc. You have access to great resources (library, computer systems, etc), and by and large it is a friendly and collegial atmosphere.

The usual perks, like discounts, benefits, gym, that go with academic life are available, and the faculty housing is amazing.
cons:
While my department is fairly well run (albeit a bit slowly sometimes), the university as a whole seems overly bureaucratic and often jury-rigged. HR is handled through a variety of outdated and frustrating computer systems; the registrar's system once crashed on the first day of school and then they stopped answering the phone. 

For a private university embarked on an ambitious building and expansion plan, NYU picks strange places to cut costs. Some of the classrooms are poorly ventilated; others are poorly lit. The pay for postdocs and adjuncts is not great, and while the maintenance workers are invariably competent, the system that keeps things like lights and clocks running leaves something to be desired.

review_title: Excellent employers, but easy to get slack
job_title: Administrative in New York, NY
pros: NYU is a good employer. The pay is good, the benefits are adequate, and the time off is excellent. The staff are unionized and have a good contract, and the university prides itself on its left-wing credentials. Everyone I work with complains bitterly about how badly they are treated, everyone I work with has been here between ten and fifty years, and no one has the slightest attention of ever leaving.
cons:
If you are an administrator and envious, you may be distressed to find that some of the staff you manage make just about as much as you do, because they have been working here forever. It doesn't bother me, because my pay is above average for the position, but it bothers some people. 

NYU is very rich indeed, and they are sloppy about personnel management. You have to set your own performance standards and hold yourself to them, because the ones set for you won't be high enough. You have to remember that any one student just about pays your yearly salary in yearly tuition, and that they should get service that reflects that.

job_title: Administrative in New York, NY
pros: New offices, most people in most other departments are nice and want to help you. Leadership development, tuition remission, seems to care about students. Colleagues seem generally nice.
cons:
The accounts payable department is the worst. I should not have to continually explain to you why you are doing things wrong. The i-Buy system is rather abhorrent as well.  Management doesn't always realize the demands that they place on their administrators. It's that attitude of "Oh, X, will take care of it" even though they ask the impossible quite frequently. Was informed that the role would be receiving help and I have not ever received qualified help. Furthermore, I am not able to disconnect from my position and must always be "on" and prepared to deal with issues. No matter how much I try to prepare for said issues, something ALWAYS happens that is out of my control. Then I get attitude for my perceived mistake when I have done everything in my power. Also, because I have no help, I have no back up and even on my sick days, I have to come in to do things before leaving because I have absolutely no backup. Trying to use PTO or sick leave is HIGHLY stressful.

To be clear my rating is for the department I work for which I will not state. I pray that the rest of NYU is better as I am seeking other job opportunities within the organization.

review_title: Experience depends on where you work
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: NYU as a whole is fairly decentralized, and things are run differently by different schools (Steinhardt, Tisch, etc.).  I think your experience depends a lot on what school you are a part of and your individual department.  I have had a great experience working for Steinhardt.  I am encouraged to challenge myself and develop professionally, and the people I work with are great.  I feel like the people I work for see me as a person and not just a warm body at a desk.  The neighborhood is great and very accessible to transit, restaurants, and city life.
cons: The salary is low compared to similar jobs.  Even after negotiating, this position was a 15% pay cut from my last job.  Also, working for a large organization can be frustrating at times because of bureaucracy - but in general the red tape at NYU is not as bad as other organizations.  NYU could stand to invest more in its facilities and work spaces.  In my office, most people have analog phones (yes, analog!) and IT put up a fight when we wanted computer upgrades.  Students are paying over $60k a year to attend this school and employees can't even get a phone with caller ID.

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros:
The job functions as a customer service/ front desk duty at NYU computer labs. It requires minimal technical knowledge on software. The work mainly involves around directing student/ school staffs of where each equipment locates. Also, the student workers are responsible with stocking printing papers, and occasional cleaning of the lab.

This is an ideal place to work as a student looking for on-campus employment. The schedules are very flexible with morning, afternoon, and closing shifts options. The facility is very well maintained, and very friendly environment. You are allowed to do homework or personal work while at work, as long as you are available when a student needs help.
cons:
Although you are working in the Technology Centers, you will learn almost zero experiences with any software or IT related trouble shootings. It is a customer service job at the front desk: directing students, helping with lending out office equipment such as headphones, and fixing printers.

Do not expect it as a job that can boost your debugging or developing skills :P

review_title: Want to move on to a different university ASAP
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Nice collegues, great community at faculty housing
cons:
1)  horrible salaries. My husband and I are assist. Professors and cannot make the ends meet with only one kid. 
2) a small group of people are favored and lots of deals happen behind closed doors. there is absolutely no transparency. It is clear that the a few people can work the system and are well treated at the expense of the rest of the faculty, which creates an unjust environment,
3) no respect from administration. They do not care about the well being of the faculty.
4) faculty housing works independently like any New York real estate company. For example,  we have been here for 2.5 years. First couple years no rent increase. Our rent was increased 11% this year. First year I had no salary raise. Second year 2.5%. So In the past couple years my salary was practically cut, because rent is about 40% of my salary after tax. I sometimes feel like I am working in a mining town in 1800s owned by the company.

If I had known all this, I would have taken my other offer two years ago. With little support to have a good career, and without a good career, I fear that i will remain stuck here

job_title: Web Developer in New York, NY
pros: In general NYU offers great work/life balance and some amazing benefits, the best is tuition remission if you're looking to get a degree.  Tons of vacation and sick days and my team in particular has been understanding and flexible when it comes to taking care of family issues and kids.  Although this differs greatly by team.  A wonderful place to work if you have kids or school or other obligations.  I have been lucky to work with some amazing people in a very friendly collaborative environment and learn a lot along the way.
cons: Biggest con is the salary, it's below market standards for sure.  The other is bureaucracy, faculty run the place and often don't understand technology.  So sometimes the decisions that are made are a bit absurd.  But that happens in any large organization.  If you're looking to work hard, stay late and get ahead - this is not the place for you.  Although it's possible, it's very difficult to accomplish in this culture.

review_title: Great place to earn experience...and a degree!
job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Tuition Remission: You get a free Undergraduate Degree, Two Free Master's Degree and one free Doctorate if you work here. The University is closed from Xmas til about Jan 2-3 and you get a free week off that doesn't count towards your vacation--and you get paid! If you're in the union, you're there from 9-5. At 5pm you're OUT, no exceptions (unless there is overtime available).
cons: Very very hard to move up and earn more money or a new title. You would need to leave your department and move to another position in order to move up. This is why people are "stuck" in the same position for years. Also, getting another position within the University may not necessarily mean you get a pay raise..especially if you're in the Union as it is the same pay (depending on the grade). So if you're a grade 8 in one position and move to another grade 8 position, you'll still make the same money. Getting moved up to a higher grade is very difficult.

review_title: Great opportunity to be involved in cutting-edge research and intellectual property issues
job_title: Contract Specialist II in New York, NY
pros: As a non-profit organization, hours are reasonable and normal 9-5, with great work-life balance. Job comes with great healthcare benefits, a 403(b), a commuter spending account, and countless others that I do not take advantage of at the moment. They paid 100% for my required CLE credits to maintain my NY bar association. Kind, friendly and intelligent colleagues.
cons: Compensation is probably not market-rate, colleagues mostly keep to themselves and there is not much after-work social events (probably both good and bad). There was no training - just learning on the job (again, could be a good and bad thing). In performing my job, I encountered lots of bureaucratic tape - as a result, I do not feel entirely independent in performing my job. The organization is so big - I'm still trying to understand how all the pieces/departments work together.

job_title: Academic Advisor in New York, NY
pros:
- Off from December 24ish to January 1
- Tuition Remission (BUT taxes are taken out of your paycheck if it is not job related I believe) 
- Depending on the school you work for, your boss can be flexible...some schools are not as flexible (Tandon, Stern, Law School, Nursing, etc...it really depends)
- Union Employees are paid bi-weekly
- Great 401K plan
- Great discounts and freebies
cons:
- Depending on the school you work for...it can operate as a caste system. There’s union employees which are usually entry level admin positions and you’ll know you’re a union employee because you’re treated differently from administrators which are non-union employees
- Administrators are paid on a monthly basis
- Pay could be low for such a prominent university 
- Medical insurance could be better. Changes are made to medications without any announcements.
- All schools operate differently so it can be a little unorganized
- Performance reviews are a one way street. You get reviewed by your supervisor but cannot review your supervisor which makes no sense.

review_title: not a good place to work
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: nothing, this place is a joke
cons: they micromanage you, and so much bullying

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: As of time of posting: Graduate students work 20 hours a week for $20 an hour. As a working graduate student, your are eligible for 90% of your student health insurance to be paid by the school. There is a very excellent and active graduate student union that will go to bat for you should you run into workplace issues, but my experience as a student worker was very positive and I think this is common. Many students do go on to be hired for full-time positions in the larger NYU universe as offices are often generous (in my experience and from what I've heard) in recommending their graduate assistants to openings throughout the administration and beyond.
cons: Hours are capped at 20 per week, and you need the office to re-hire you at the beginning of each new semester. This means that continued employment is not 100% guaranteed for the length of your degree; however, offices are usually very clear about the length of their need for student assistants and most students work with the office for as long as they want or until they graduate, at which time they become ineligible to continue employment in that role.

job_title: Procurement Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great opportunity for educational advancement
cons: Culture is not as professional in all areas

review_title: Great stepping stone if you have a good outlook
job_title: Fitness Attendant in New York, NY
pros: I worked as a fitness attendant in the NYU Brooklyn Athletics Facility. It was a great time and I enjoyed the things I learned about the fitness facility. I saw a lot of my classmates while at work and I also made some great friends while I worked there. My favorite moments revolved around that workspace and I can personally attest that working there has made me a much more social person.
cons: We were sometimes unable to do basic things such as reading a book or messing around with the computer because there was a need to watch the patrons that were engaged in physical activity. I understand the need to be carefully vigilant of what people do but it slowly might drain the morale of the employees. They also took away the right to play our own music in the gym this made it even worse. Also hearing that the employees in the other facilities had it easier than us and were given more freedoms made it hard to continue working there.

job_title: Senior UNIX Systems Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Working at NYU makes a lot of sense if you have a family at home and are seeking job security. Management usually makes sure not to "waste" your potential and offers a lot of opportunities to further your job skills and let's you advance in your career IF you end up in a department that has opportunities like that. Some of the key benefits: paid maternity/paternity leave, generous retirement benefit (employee pays 5% of gross, NYU adds 10% of your gross on top), paid tuition for you and your children, most of the perks students get are available to employees as well, merit salary increase of 1.5% - 3% annually, and many more.
cons: Things move very slowly here. Since Sexton took the reigns NYU turned to be more corporate than what one may expect from an academic institution. Indecisive upper management and a lot of red tape to avoid personal responsibilities in those circles.

review_title: Post-doctoral fellow in the chemistry department (Research scientist)
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Great faculty and co-workers.  Everyone at NYU is willing to take time and help, which is better than the cut-throat environment seen at many research universities.  The shared instrument facilities are kept well with almost any instrument you would ever need to do research available at any time.  The staff is very helpful.  Full health benefits and post-doc housing at Washington Square park.  Overall, it's a really excellent place to do a post-doc.
cons: The pay is the national standard for a post-doctoral fellow, which is not really great if you live in the most expensive city in the US.  It is difficult to make orders or ever get an answer from payroll.  NYU is up and coming, but it is still not considered one of the leaders in the academic field for chemistry.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: friendly and intelligent people; beautiful facilities; high credibility; reasonable pay; union
cons: like any large business, it takes a while to get anything done.  there's so many hoops to jump through or papers to fill out to do any one simple task.  also there is not a lot of definitive processes in how to perform tasks so each charge takes quite a long time.  also, some of the buildings are isolated from others and some floors are made up of entire departments.  therefore, it can be hard if you are new and you position is one per department since you are alone on a floor.  it makes it hard to acclimate.  assignments are given and no one shows you how to carry anything out.  you have to do a lot of guess work or create a wide network of advisers from varying departments.  it's no one's fault since the departments can't help being isolated but there is no real training involved.

review_title: Some colleges at NYU are better to work for than others
job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Amazing benefits, lots of growth and promotional opportunities, tuition remission for employees, love working with academics and students who are passionate about their subjects, most of the university is fairly casual, the best area of the University to work, in my option, is the Division of Arts & Sciences
cons: Very bureaucratic because of its size, horrible Accounts Payable department, uneven culture throughout the university, some departments are lovely and efficient, others are toxic,  did not have good experience working with the Law School, Stern or NYUCD

review_title: COVID: HR doesn't care about the well-being of their employees
job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: Tuition Remission (but not tax-free)
cons: All departments are required to have staff in the office whether or not all of their courses and events are online, despite requests from Department Chairs who see no reason for employees to be put at risk. Administrative staff must travel on public transit to sit alone in empty offices, even though faculty were given the option to be work virtually or in-person. Organizationally, NYU is a nightmare. Getting an answer about anything (from the finance department, registrars office, etc.) can take weeks and sometimes you never get a response. If you do get a response, it can differ depending on the person you get in contact with. Furthermore, the technical systems they have in place are inefficient and dated. The overall issue is that employees at NYU are overworked and underpaid, and staff aren't given the resources they need. It's shocking that the high cost of attending NYU does not improve the working conditions of the staff that keep the school running.

job_title: Administrative in New York, NY
pros:
Good brand name on your resume
Some interesting things happening across the University that you can tangentially be a part of
Decent pay relative to other educational institutions
cons:
The School of Professional Studies itself is one of the worst managed organizations I've ever seen.
Terrible morale, randomly fluctuating goals, constant turnover of employees, faculty, and staff due to the difficult environment 
Some members of upper management are borderline cruel in their public treatment of employees (not necessarily faculty) [and not "I'm a special snowflake" kind of things. I mean out-of-the-blue,  jaw-droppingly insulting in the middle of large meetings, apparently for no reason other than spite kind of thing]
I left to another university as soon as I was able to (for much less salary) and haven't looked back.

review_title: A mixed bag but overall good
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: NYU has great benefits- from medical/dental to tuition reimbursements to a very active campus- there are always events happening somewhere (including many a free lunch). The work itself can be rewarding- depending on the department. You can have a good level of autonomy and there are many opportunities to carve out your own niche.
cons: Again, your mileage may vary based on the department/school that you work for- NYU is broken into several schools that operate fairly independently. While there are a lot of great people working at NYU, there are many who are not competent and not nice and they are just entrenched in their positions. The further up the chain you go, the less oversight there is. Do not expect to be paid well unless you are dean's level or have serious connections.

review_title: One of the better jobs for sure
job_title: 3D Specialist in New York, NY
pros: I worked at the Laguardia Studio lab within NYU. It was pretty cool since I got to learn a lot about 3D technologies and work with amazing people. Overall I would say the pros are competitive pay compared to other on-campus jobs you can get at the university, and the access to some of the latest 3D related technologies. And if you know your stuff, you get to work on some really interesting problems and solve challenges.
cons: Some aspects of the job can be difficult due to the level of knowledge needed to operate all of the different software and tooling. A lot of the clients that come in end up needing solutions that are not so cut and dry. Without having in depth knowledge of all the different tools, you'll find yourself always asking upper management for help. If you don't pay attention you can end up making expensive mistakes. Some clients are also a pain in the a** to deal with.

review_title: NYU - the Starbucks of Higher Education
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: The NYU brand.  The Deans were very supportive.   The office space was historic and cutting edge.  Good intentions and well connected to the community.  The students were well accomplished, committed to making a difference, and smart. The President is leaving, so the incoming President has a huge opportunity for focus less on growth and more on quality.
cons: The pay was exceptionally low for the tuition that students pay.  The students were more demanding, entitled and somewhat less driven than I would have expected.  NYU is expanding so much in NYC, domestically, and globally - yet not convinced they pay as much attention to the quality of their programs (for the cost).  NYU felt more like a business franchising it's name with many cookie cutter approaches than an educational institution committed to learning, growth, and the student/faculty experience.

job_title: Academic Advisor in New York, NY
pros:
-The staff I worked with was *amazing.* Everyone was excellent at what they did.
-The students were for the most part great to work with and root for.
-I got lots of hands-on leadership experience and was encouraged to try new things and innovate.
cons:
-The caseload for advising in-and-of itself was manageable, but when balanced with a secondary responsibility (and everyone on the advising team had a second role as well), the job could definitely become more than a 40-hour a week commitment at times.
-Due to double responsibilities (being an advisor along with being in charge of another program or center), you'd expect salaries to be higher. I felt like I should have been paid 10-15K more for the work I was doing.

job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: While at NYU I had wonderful colleagues who were passionate about what they did. They made working until 8 or 9pm bearable and coming into work in the morning pleasant.
cons: Many administrative positions (specifically, "administrative aides") at NYU are union with little room for growth and no room for salary negotiations. Vacation and holidays are pre-determined and although you are expected to work overtime with and by your managers ("directors/assistant directors/associate directors"), you aren't always compensated for the time properly (while managers awarded extra vacation days and time off). Furthermore, even if you went beyond the call of duty or led an extraordinary project, no monetary bonuses we allowed, and all other "rewards" were completely off-record. Lastly, the bureaucracy at NYU is among the worst of private higher education institutions and systems operations are rather antiquated (i.e., grades are still mailed to one central room on Scantron forms).

review_title: Find the right office and you'll be happy
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros:
- NYU is NYC's largest employer. That's a lot of employees and a lot of room for error. The environment of NYU is that it likes to promote from within when possible. 
- With the previous observation in mind (not all divisions are the same), there is a strong sense of improvement and betterment for the students. 
- It is a very forward thinking place to work and does not shy away from being outspoken about diversity and LGBTQ rights.
cons:
- If you move from within you are required by NYU policy to enter at the same salary if the job is in the same band. 
- Higher Ed is not for everyone as it's a very relationship driven environment. If you aren't into that you will be unhappy.

job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: great benefits including 10% 403b match,  lots of retail affinity discounts.  Unique opportunity to work with, or attend events with top people in every walk of life.  One of the chicest, hippest neighborhoods in the city -- Greenwich Village!  Work with people who care about more than just money.
cons: very very very bureaucratic.  Business practices, and work culture vary widely division to division and sometimes from department to department within in division.  Absolutely must be active in office politics to advance.

review_title: Okay benefits, but everything else is terrible.
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: The location was nice, and there were some good benefits like tuition reimbursement. I worked at Stern, and they tried to have semi-regular happy hours for employees, which was a nice way to show appreciation.
cons: The offices at Stern were filled with mice and rather depressing overall. The leadership is terrible. Everything is very political, which means a lot of dishonesty and a lack of transparency. Everyone treats the faculty like gods, but nobody seems to be too concerned about students and whether or not they are getting their money's worth. The leadership is very greedy and rely on NYU's name to do the heavy lifting. Also, I had come from a SUNY school outside of the city, and they wanted to pay me less than I was making for the same role.

job_title: Facilities Manager in New York, NY
pros: Family oriented professional group. Generous time off. Empathetic Senior Management group. More than ample latitude to make decisions on your own regarding your portfolio. The Facility Manager is regarded as the utmost professional with a very attuned support staff to promote a successful work environment. Your worst day here is a cake walk elsewhere
cons: NYU is undergoing a massive realignment in business practices and development. At times it takes too long to get something accomplished. If you come from a fast paced environment, it will take some getting used to the slow pace. At the same time this can be a plus. Building relationships will be a challenge, this is an academic setting and everything thrives on relationships. Care must be considered so as not to jeopardize your goals.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Ample vacation.  That's about it.
cons: My experience at NYU SPS has been absolutely terrible. There may be other schools and positions that make working at NYU positive, but DO NOT TAKE ANY ROLE AT NYU SPS. The Dean is not qualified to lead. He has completely outdated and unreasonable policies, and the morale in my department is lower than any place I've worked. I have also tried to transition to other roles within NYU, and have tried to get promoted within my department, to no avail. They say the support internal hires, but that has not been my or my colleagues' experiences. NYU has branded themselves well - I thought working here would be a dream, but it's all in the marketing. It's phony. You're better off elsewhere.

review_title: Good pay, but not good enough for the headaches
job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Pay and benefits are good (not great) for similar positions.  Staff are very hard workers, and it is a pleasure working with them.  Hours and time off are reasonable.
cons: It is a large, bureaucratic institution for not just the student, but the employees as well.  Communication from upper management is almost non-existent.  Upper management only deigns to speak to use when they have an idea of how we can do our jobs better (regardless of the fact that they don't seem to understand what our jobs are).  Upper management blatantly does not care about its employees (and I do mean blatantly - there are stories I could tell which would horrify, but then I might lose some of my anonymity).

job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros:
- Pretty good pay for the work expected.
- Very friendly staff, especially fellow clerical workers.
- Being around and working alongside professors fosters a greater appreciation for education.
- Reduced cost of education at NYU - practically free for undergrad (Only registration fee is required). It's more than worth it working at NYU just for the free undergraduate education.
cons:
- Students can be annoying and disrespectful.
- Can become boring.
- You interact with a lot of people. It's very easy to get sucked into 20-40 minute conversations about nothing. Meanwhile you probably have a lot of work to do but don't want to be rude so you end up staying late.

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits particularly for vacation and retirement savings. I was lucky enough to take advantage of tuition remission and received my master's degree from NYU. My fellow admin in non-supervisory roles are among the best.
cons: There's been a change in management the past 4 years and the new leadership is godawful. Most of the old guard have been viciously fired or forced to retire with no compassion. And there is no rhyme or reason why people are being let go. If you are lucky enough to be offered severance, they will extract a promise that you will quietly, never speak about why you are being let go, and never return to NYU - ever!

review_title: Union technical position, no growth, no challenge
job_title: IT Support Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Good but not great tuition remission benefits. Ok health/vis/dental. Low key. Reasonable work life balance. Good location and a lot of ways to get involved with the community outside of work.
cons: NYU is vast but some departments run as many small fiefdoms. Not always easy to navigate politically if you end up in a small group and want to move to another. Compensation for union technical roles are below par but so are the challenge and effort required. Certain managers lack flexibility in scheduling classes during the workday. I know this sounds like a stretch request, but I worked in a department that was open 7a-10p and my colleagues agreed to cover during my classes. You also have to factor in that the tuition remission is a huge part of the compensation package for some people who are working there. Not being able to take advantage of it is problematic.

review_title: Going global with a great respect for diversity of talent & ideas
job_title: Human Resources Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Opportunities for learning are everywhere for a young college grad & young professional. NYU tuition at a fraction of the cost/nearly free? Yes please!  Winter break is also definitely a great perk. Starting salaries are reasonable; starting on, it was the highest I even considered applying for, and I only got it because I had an in from working with them in the past as a student. Innovation is encouraged.
cons: Your work-life balance can get thrown for a loop if you let it. There is a definite cap for some roles, and growth is often attained by leaving as opposed to staying straight through.

review_title: Faculty Fellow review - and not tenure track
job_title: Faculty Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Excellent facilities, great students (generally!) and access to so many resources within an urban university.
cons: One of the most corporate entities I have ever worked for. Not much transparency, lots of bureaucracy, and a lot of data that points to a general disdain for nurturing teaching talent at the entry level. Great place for someone already established in an academic career, but tough for someone with a newly minted PHD, no matter how much support is offered - the faculty fellow positions are too short to make a difference in the program, and too badly paid (at least in the Humanities) to be sustainable.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Work scheduling cam be flexible at certain points in the year. Several opportunities for travel, if traveling for work is something that appeals to you. Workers (on the whole) are afforded a respectable amount of autonomy- they receive support when needs but are not micromanaged.
cons: While some parts of the year are relatively calm (or at least manageable), other parts of the year can be unpredictability stressful. It also  wouldn't hurt, of course, to have a *slightly* higher base salary, in part due to the amount of "after hours" commitments we end up being strapped to, but also because newly hired Admissions Officers who are coming in with more work experience deserve to have their past work experiences rewarded with a salary that is suited to their experience.

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are very good, time off good too. free and discounted classes are good so there was no problem there.
cons:
HR has watch lists of the people who they want to groom and promote. If you aren't a friend or on that watch list you are for the better part ignored and/or neglected from promotions, information, opportunities. If your immediate manager doesn't like you; you will be dead in the water while people with less skills and experience are treated like gold.

Management is very top heavy as well. It feels like there are more managers than employees.

review_title: Good training but you have to initiate all opportunities
job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros:
- Good work/family balance
- Opportunites to make money on the side by getting involved in faculty projects
-  Pretty good stipend and health benefits package compared with other PhD programs
-  Faculty willing to connect students with their professional contacts, important for developing dissertation research and finding jobs
cons:
- Students have to initiate all research and job opportunities.  You must aggressively go after what you want or you will fail. 
-  NYU does not have a strong research reputation in many fields.

review_title: Beware if you report to Department Chair(s)
job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
- For most (keyword here), there is good work/life balance.
- Great benefits and vacation time.
- Opportunity to grow from within.
- Tuition remission.
cons:
- Awful politics.
- Oftentimes, relationships between faculty and staff is lacking, though there are a few gems.
- Entitled students.
- Some departments are lovely, others are toxic.
- For non-union positions, there is no support if management wants to get rid of you; HR will not help you and often side with professors/management regardless of the circumstance.
- Places a significant amount of power in the department chairs, which can be dangerous if he/she is mentally unstable (i.e., alcoholic). Some chairs abuse this power and hire/fire people based on personal preference. Historically, HR does very little to help.

review_title: Read this if you are about to be hired--Admin Aides--Clerical Union Employees--Code 106
job_title: Administrative Aide I in New York, NY
pros: HR will tell you that they cannot pay you more because your pay is capped by the union contract. This is a lie. The union contract regulates MINIMUM pay. NYU can pay you anything above the amounts set in the contract. Push for more and tell them the contract regulates minimum pay. You deserve it and they can pay it.
cons: HR never approves raises. Never. So get the highest salary you can when you get hired because you will only get the union contract raises after that. The union is great and fights for you but NYU makes it impossible to get more. They don't value the lowest people. It's all about the faculty. So fight for yourself.

review_title: The school has great benefits, job security and a really comfortable atmosphere to work in
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The benefits of the job are great.  Also, the people were all really friendly and made for a fun time at work and feeling like you were all in it together.
cons: The pay seems to be competitive only at certain levels.  Also, while the camaraderie and constant working together with others can be nice, it can also be taxing and having people stretched less thin would make things easier.

review_title: Overqualified employees benefit from great local support but hurt by bureaucracy of large institution
job_title: Program Associate in New York, NY
pros: Locally, good chance that your boss is a committed individual, who cares about his/her work and therefore your performance. Good opportunities for growth within the field. Tuition remission.
cons: Large bureaucracy that uses poor communication based on unclear policies that can, if the employee is not properly informed by their own shear determination to understand and dig up information, have a detrimental effect on the employees income. Little room for advancement. High turnover of staff at the same level, making institutional memory a problem, which can impact your job.

review_title: Watch the future unfold, very slowly.
job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros: It is fulfilling to work at an institution that is plugged in to so much that is changing in so many fields of art technology and science and in so many places around the world.  Benefits are fairly good.  So much changes, that it never gets boring.
cons: Don't expect to get paid high enough to live in the neighborhood.  Administrative jobs do not come with housing, so expect to have a long commute.  There are a lot of legacy systems and red tape and levels of bureaucracy, so do not expect a fresh, cutting edge office life.

review_title: Stern IT. Great Culture. Flexible. Opportunity to Learn.
job_title: Lab Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The hours here are pretty flexible, so they help organize your work time with whatever else is on you schedule. This is also a possible work-study opportunity, so they definitely helps students who can utilize that. They also a chance for you to learn about anything IT related, if you make the effort.
cons: There's not much to say about cons. Sometimes work can be boring if you're trying to be active. Also, upper management can be caught in gridlock at times, so things in the department generally stay the same year in, year out.

review_title: A good environment to work in.
job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission makes going back to school much more affordable!
cons:
The compensation is lacking.  However, I come from the nonprofit field and comparatively NYU's pay is much more lucrative.  The real bonus comes with the benefits.  Depending upon which code you fall under (the type of position you fulfill) you can have a range of benefits.  Some position benefits include tuition remission for yourself, spouse, and children; very low expense health care; decreased gym membership cost.

On another note, departments other than the one I work directly in often run antiquated systems and use old procedures and policies which slow down the efficiency and abilities of the organization.

job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: For the first time, I did what I loved in research and application - rubbing shoulders with the thought leaders in academia and industry.
cons: The system at NYU does not make it easy sometimes to do simple things - like get reimbursed for expenses.  You typically have to run all over manhattan to file simple paper work.  They really should make it easier for you to find and keep housing near where you work.  I eventually got lucky, but it was not easy at the start when you need it to be easy.

job_title: Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, excellent management, consistent supervision, respect shown by all levels. I learned a great deal from my colleagues and never felt like I was "beneath" anyone that I worked with, even though they were my supervisors.
cons: research is a bit unpredicatable in terms of funding, so I was let go when study ended bc there was not another position available right away. Salary could be a bit higher

job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Decent benefits, convenient locations, mostly near Washington Square Park
cons: Unbelievably incompetent administration.  Huge groups of the university - including Accounts Payable and Human Resources - simply do not function.  The simplest tasks are too much for them.  There are a huge number of employees who've been there a decade + and don't have two brain cells left to rub together.  Even with endless perseverance and every shred of logic, accuracy, and human decency on your side, you cannot get these groups to accomplish anything.  Everything is a fight, everything is done wrong 300 times before, if you're incredibly lucky and persistent, it's done right. It's like working in an insane asylum from the 1950's.  Every day I feel like I'm in the twilight zone.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Overall great to do research at, good benefits, great city location, especially if you are young. Opportunities for collaboration, but alot of fundamental research work and less applications-based approach or collaborations with corporations, if that is what you are looking for. Good work life balance. Great facilities that they are constantly investing in. Overall good.
cons: Institution in general straddles several areas: performing arts, business, sciences, etc,  so while you get a great diversity and cross-talk between disciplines, you also dont really get the depth of the science or biomedical field as it applies to industry, except however your research group is organized. Just depends on what you are looking for. This could potentially not really be an issue for you. Just be sure what you are there for.

job_title: Librarian in New York, NY
pros: Great colleagues, a supportive and exciting environment for instruction and research, extensive collections, pretty healthy work environment. People are not hung up on punctuality which is a big pro for me personally lol.
cons: The salaries for librarian are not great relative to the cost of living in NYC, the NYU Libraries are also a very large organization so it takes a while to get to know everyone in the different departments. It's very busy in certain parts of the year, so it can be a stressful job at times too. But if you like a fast-paced library that can also be a good thing.

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: The best thing about working for any academic institution is the students, they are a creative and reinvigorating force.
cons: UpperUpper management is clueless about what should be the mission of the institution. They are too fixated on bringing on so called "world class" faculty in order to raise their academic profile. Like the way the Yankees buy talent to build their team. Instead they should be raising their profile by continuing to PRODUCE world class thinkers and doers and showcasing them!

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New York, NY
pros: best thing about working in NYU is getting the Village experience that all movies featuring NYC have mandatory scenes on.
cons: Benefits aren't great. And although there's a partial match towards retirement plans, they're not as good as what you can get from other private schools. Especially considering the tuition NYU charges its students. Wonder where all that money goes.

job_title: Post Production Technician in New York, NY
pros: Bennie are great, great staff to work with, they spend money to get you training and certifications, supervisors are attentive to the employees needs as long as it don't interfere with the mission of the dept., pretty flexible when it comes to education, theres much respect for military employees, pay is OK but definitely not exploitive, state of the art equipment, on occasion there would be free food during meetings and celebrations, and benefits extend to the immediate family.
cons: Brown bag your meals because its expensive eating around here, parking is horrible but mass transit is available, promotions are not too frequent because no one wants to leave, and there is a lot of office politics.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great place to work while taking classes and taking advantage of tuition remission.  Workload is not too intense which can allow you to have some focus on your classes.  Very flexible schedule to make room for classes.  Easy to move around to other NYU positions after you pass a year employment.  The atmosphere is great.  Not so much micro-management here.
cons: Don't get stuck in this position as it can get very comfortable.  If you're not taking advantage of getting a Bachelors Degree, Masters, or PHd, you are wasting your time as you can find better opportunities and get higher salary elsewhere.

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Large network of people to interact with, tuition remission (for full-time employees, you're eligible for 90%-off tuition after one full year and you must apply and get accepted), retirement planning, health and wellness services
cons: Very political (people like to prove their team's worth and their own value to others), very little trust of others, no communal goals or team spirit you get at for-profit organizations, out-of-date technology, and online processes, overcrowded buildings and restrooms, low pay and salaries, no room for growth unless someone leaves or gets promoted, lack of culture

review_title: Great people and environment, but too much pressure from upstairs
job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: NYU does their best to hire great people and it shows. Every person I have worked with here has been amazing in their own right, at their job and outside of the office doing great things. Most offices of NYU are welcoming, creative environments that foster great working relations. They do a wonderful job adjusting for student workers and making work fit with peoples outside interests, projects, and responsibilities.
cons: Since NYU is a private university and claims to be an exceedingly liberal one, their message can seem a bit hypocritical at times when you see the back workings.  It can be tough to balance your ideals with the ideals you are charged with portraying the university as holding.

review_title: Student Employee in Various Departments: Overall a Great Experience
job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: I worked as a student employee in several departments at NYU during my undergraduate tenure: Department of Hebrew and Judaic Studies, Liberal Studies, the ID Card Center and the Office of Residential Life and Housing Services. In each department the administrators and managers were helpful, encouraging and friendly. I had an especially amazing time working for the Office of Residential Life and Housing Services, as I received training, both in practical skills and best practices, that will apply to any industry for years to come.
cons: None that I can think of! I did not stay on as a full time employee after graduation, but NYU loves to hire former students after they graduate.

review_title: I would have expected more from NYU, to be honest
job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
Some great and friendly coworkers. 
Great benefits such as vacation, tuition reimbursement and work/life balance, at least in my office and when I worked there.
cons:
Some serious conflicts between some of the staff members. 
Unethical relationship between employee and manager There was this romantic couple where one was the manager and the other directly reporting to that manager. Everybody knew that they were an item and had been for the longest time. Still, one was reporting to the other, which (in addition to being just plain wrong) seemed very awkward. 
Seemed like the leadership were jumping to conclusions and not thinking things through at times. 
NYU has a lot of money but salaries are generally low for non-faculty.

review_title: Work/Life balance depends on the department you are working in. Steinhardt School of Music need not apply..
job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
Great Staff, Great Compensation, Creative Environment.

It allowed me to gain more financial experience which was a good thing. Otherwise, I would not have stayed.
cons: I temporarily worked as an employee for Steinhardt School of music. It was a great learning experience but extremely disorganized and lacking professionalism. Each person was given the tasks of doing a two person job and many permanent employees often complained about the lack of raises or compensation they received for the work. The person in my previous position as the Budget Coordinator often worked 70-80 hours per week. Definitely enough to turn me off.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: One cannot pass up the opportunity to continue your education at nominal cost and that was the greatest benefit. I loved working there until...(see Cons).
cons: Management values profit over people, at least where I last worked. The good experiences that I gained in my short time there were quickly extinguished with the swift fall of a broad ax swung without discretion and or consideration for exceptional past performance. I, and a few others, were tossed out like yesterday's trash all to save a little $.

review_title: Good environment for a physics teaching adjunct
job_title: Teaching Adjunct in New City, NY
pros: The rooms are large and well equipped. The equipment is modern and the lab staff is well prepared, handy and helpful. The website interface is intuitive. Organizing a class using the web tools is very easy and spares a lot of time. The University organizes events regularly to connect its faculty members. There is a lot of freedom in organizing the work and the classes.
cons: Being an expensive school, often its students associate paying a lot with getting good grades. As a result, they sometimes cannot accept bad grades as a feedback on the quality of their work and they might expect good grades regardless  to the amount of efforts they put in the classes.

job_title: Assistant to the Chair in New York, NY
pros: NYU provides its staff, who are unionized, secure employment and extensive benefits. Its health care options are very good; so is the opportunity to take continuing education courses (at a significant discount) or receive tuition remission if you or a family member is enrolled in an academic program.
cons: The University is very large and its administration can be lethargic, which makes certain aspects of day-to-day work frustrating.  Apparently, non-NYU employees can find a job search challenging, since the University promotes from within.

review_title: NYU: a discounted education if you can put up with the Loons
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission!!  This is a great chance to get a master's when you don't know what to do after college.  You can also take whatever class you want pretty much - they love educating the workforce!
cons: Like a lot of other places... it is a bureaucracy.  There is a lot of paper-pushing that goes on here.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great location.  If you like the city it is great.  The village is a great place to be.  Also great research opportunities.  Housing options are not that great for graduate students.  Pay is comparable to others but expences in the city are much higher.  I am not sure how this will change now that they busted the grad student union.  Health care is OK.  To get dental care it is very expensive.  I do not like sexton so much.
cons: Your expenses will be very high.  To get an offordable housing you have to live very far away.  Also, the administration is weird under Sexton.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Depending on the department and teh management therein, NYU can be a great opportunity to learn and grow as an administrator.  Salaries at NYU are more competitive than most other higher education institutions and the benefits package is also fairly strong!
cons: Depending on your department and the senior managers you work for, the work experience and staff management is driven by middle managers that don't know how to manage people yet they want results.  The school's adminnistration has become MUCH more bureaucratic in the last 5-8 years which has had a negatie impact on administrators and consequently services to teh students!

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: High energy workplace with constant learning and skill enhancement opportunities.  Great people who really care about the students and making them better; staff are very friendly and sincerely want to help each other whenever possible.  Healthy growth means there are many new opportunities every semester/year.
cons: Huge organization that can be confusing and hard to navigate, especially as first.  Official on boarding/orientation is a bit lacking, so try to buddy-up with a current staffer to learn how to access resources and acquire tips and best practices.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros:
Working with young people is fulfilling and inspiring. Every job or department is different, so if you want to work with students, check that the job you apply for will have student contact. 
Good benefits, generous time off, most jobs are really 9-5.
cons: Sometimes there can be politics, or bitter or disorganized faculty, or entitled students.  Also, faculty are often treated better than staff, which can be frustrating. But that can happen at any university. These issues are only a small percentage of the whole, but research the department carefully before you decide.

review_title: Cool downtown place to work, but top heavy management.
job_title: Administrative Director in New York, NY
pros: Great location, stimulating environment.  There's a tremendous variety of experience at the University - everything from molecular biology to musical performance to hardcore business education.  An employee can move among these different areas if so motivated.
cons: There's a constant tension concerning budgets and personnel.  There's quite a top heavy senior administration with more vice-presidents and assistant vice-presidents and special counsel and etc. at the same time there are threats of no salary increase for the general professional staff.

review_title: Overall, an excellent place to be
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros:
- Great benefits and a wonderful environment if you value being at an institution of higher ed (public lectures, cultural events, concerts, etc.)
- Good job stability; many people have been here for 10+ years
- Great work/life balance
- Other administrators and staff are generally very pleasant colleagues
cons:
- Can be bogged down in slow-moving bureaucracy 
- Depending on your credentials in the private sector, you'll take a pay cut (but the benefits and work/life balance could more than make up for it, depending on your priorities)
- Unclear room for promotion and growth; no direct path so you will have to look out for opportunities yourself

review_title: Only work as an undergrad if you're really cash strapped
job_title: Operations Monitor in New York, NY
pros: Training is largely unnecessary. There literally isn't any need for it because almost anything you will do will be based off of common sense. Its a great way to get paid without doing anything :)
cons: The management can either be demanding or really laid back. More of an in between would be perfect, however, I don't think such a thing exists.

review_title: NYU Stern is a thriving community. Being part of which is an honor and opportunity to grow personally and professionally
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Great community, very collaborative,excellent ground for learning and professional growth. Potential to educate oneself continuously, paid by school (limitations apply :)).
cons: Salaries are not the best, although benefits provided can outweigh the salary requirements. Yet, higher education is not the best place to make lots of money.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Work directly with a professional staff on various projects. Able to work with staff on professional presentations for natioal conferences and journal articles. Able to attend professional development courses. Excellent benfits package.
cons: Difficult to advance, often a good option before entering graduate school. Position does not pay very well (low to mid 30's).  Most research assistants stay with the organization for a few years before going to graduate school. Depending on the position you can work a lot of overtime and weekends.

job_title: Information Technology in New York, NY
pros:
Great opportunity to meet and cooperate with a wide range of fields.
Great flexibility, the jobs works around your hours.
Amazing bosses who do their best to assist you in your job.
cons: Hours are limited due to the amount of student workers.  Since hours work around your schedule as well as others, you are limited by their schedules as bosses try to  maximize hours for everyone.

review_title: Great benefits and job security, but very low pay and no room for advancement.
job_title: Technical Staff in New York, NY
pros: I had very pleasant coworkers, job security, and great benefits.
cons: The pay was really, really low, so unless you're taking advantage of tuition remission, it's just a low-paying job.  There is also very little room for advancement.  In the end, I had to leave, or else I would have been stuck in the same low-level job forever.  NYU is a great place to work for those just starting their careers or those close to retirement, but if you're in between those two phases, you might have to move on.

job_title: Communications Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Great health, retirement,  and family benefits for full-time staff and administrators. Flexible work environment that provides numerous learning opportunities, whether through professional development or the University's generous tuition remission policy. Increased focus on diversity and affordability due to push at senior executive level.
cons: Highly bureaucratic, which makes approval processes unnecessarily long and tedious. Departments tend to be overly protective of projects/functions, which hinders trust and collaboration across units. Slow to promote within ranks.

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: tuition remission, gym, retirement package, vacation time, resources of a big university
cons: very political atmosphere, incompetent managers, many coworkers who do not know how to communcate or have basic business skills, people always trying to pass the buck/blame others if something goes wrong, no positive reinforcement from managers--you only hear from them if something goes wrong, managers don't value their employees

job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros: Good opportunities, growing organization both in the US and overseas.  New campus in Abu Dhabi and Shanghai.  10 Global sites.
cons: Politics is more intense as compared to working for the Federal, State, or Local government agencies.  Faculty are treated as first class citizens, everybody else is second class.  Administration is somewhat powerless and takes a long time to make important decisions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: it is in NY, the campus is in the center, you get relatively cheap housing.
cons: Very poorly paid, and no rights at all. You are at the mercy of your supervisor. If it is a nice human being you may only have to work 24/7, if not you may have to handle other unexpected behaviour that are not controlled by NYU. I truly believe that NYU should check on how badly the postdocs and phd students are treated in some labs..

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: People, benefits, progressive ideas to advance higher ed, good vacation time, excellent location, mobility within university, laid back work environment if you are in the right department
cons: Low vacancies make it hard to be promoted, a lot of red tape, too de-centralized - creating unfair policies between different schools; if one school has a work from home policy, another school won’t, etc. very unfair salaries between people at same levels in different schools.

review_title: Good opportunity for NYU entry and those who self-manage well
job_title: Program Administrator (Was) in New York, NY
pros: Location! Beautiful setting in the Puck Building at Houston and Lafayette in Soho. Colleagues- smart, ambitious, learning focused. Opportunity- within Wagner, the opportunities might be limited, depending on your capability, but NYU is your broader network. Benefits- job related (and approved) education is covered, the benefits package is comprehensive.
cons: Senior leadership lost its anchor of 3 decades to another school after repeatedly promoting and Dean'ing younger climbers. As a result, management is operating from a re-active stance to haphazard position filling. That was 2007. The ship may be back on course by now.

job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: It was great to work with smart people when I started there. Great benefits and pay for someone starting out.
cons: I was disappointed to find there wasn't a lot of movement. Rather than promoting, people seemed to always be hired externally, which would then mean a learning curve, and a lot of retraining. It was disappointing to feel like it was hard to move up.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Work with Multiple Technologies
Service Oriented
Benefits (Tuition Remission, Retirement)

If you're near retirement or in need of very generous tuition benefits, join NYU or any other higher education institution.
cons:
1) Calcified culture
2) Very difficult to let go of underperforming talent
3) Very difficult to accomplish tasks in a timely fashion

4) If you are someone who wants to "get lost" inside a machine that doesn't hold people accountable, join NYU or any other higher education institution.

5) NYU fails to attract and retain quality talent because of the general culture present in higher education. That culture rewards political favors, unnecessary and counterproductive "consensus building" which can stretch what should be a 6 month project to several years, and does not pay prevailing wages. 

Example: In a corporate environment, what should take a day or two in terms of an email response to a query could take a week or more at NYU. That is, unfortunately, the de facto response and the culture of sluggishness that exists in NYU and almost all higher education institutions.

6) On the latter point, NYU does offer very generous Tuition Remission and Retirement matching benefits (though they have been skimping on the tuition remission component in recent years). However, if you are not interested in attaining more education or are not in need of turbo-charging your retirement accounts, NYU will likely drive you batty.

Unfortunately these elements in combination lead to "older" employees who are looking to hold on as long as possible to get themselves to retirement, or get their children through school, and very "young" employees who are merely trying to get through school and get out as quickly as possible.

Many of the remaining people in between fall into a category of being "unhireable" anywhere outside of the higher education environment.

7) Another NYU failing, and likely higher education in general, falls to the apportionment of funds for various departments. 

Ex: NYU will spend millions on its faculty on such frivolous items as underwriting mortgages with *very* generous benefits for deans, loans for cars and other non-education related expenses for professors, etc.

In the meantime, they will cut headcount for critical services such as IT, Security, etc. Or cut services that help offset recruitment issue woes such as Tuition Remission.

Another example of this failure is the use of high-priced consultants instead of hiring competent employees at prevailing wages.

Rather than hire an extra 2-3 employees to support critical systems, an expenditure which might cost NYU $200,000-$300,000/yr at prevailing wages and benefits, NYU will pay consultants $1,000,000 for the same work, year after year.

This is because those consultants are part of a different budget than is counted for full time headcount. This ensures that the ultimate bearers of those costs, the parents and students, will continue to see their tuition rise unnecessarily.

These and many other issues make NYU, and many higher education institutions, highly inefficient and ineffective, yet obscenely expensive, places to work and finance.

NYU could do much, much, better.

review_title: The perfect place for student on campus emplyment
job_title: Web Publishing Student Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Everyone is very respectful and diversified. The do understand that you are a student worker and have many other things to take care of while working.
cons: I haven't had any negative experience so far in any ways.

review_title: Great benefits for someone pursuing a Masters or PhD.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in New York, NY
pros: The benefits package, even for graduate students is very comprehensive and substantial.  PPO plans are quite generous and cost about $30 per month.  At NYU each employee pays the same percentage of their salary to gain benefits (for a graduate student, this is very little, so the cost is very minimal).
cons: As a student it is hard to determine exactly how long is permissible to take vacation.  While some take loads, others are in labs that do not permit this.

review_title: Overall great place to work.  Active community and lots of resources to further your career.
job_title: Project Manager, Information Technology in New York, NY
pros:
-You can join special interest groups for just about anything you're interested in.  Everyone is willing to help, provide referrals, and share knowledge
-Tuition remission.  It's NYU!  Getting any degree from NYU is a good thing for your career and since it's one of the most expensive universities in the world, the tuition remission is a huge plus.
-If you are diligent, you can really advance your career by taking advantage of the resources available.  Not just degrees, but reaching out to thought leaders and faculty, being a part of the community and making connections, attending events to learn and network, volunteering, etc.
-Lots of discounts for a variety of things
-Once you work at NYU you can move around the organization.  There's lots of career advancement opportunities throughout the university
-Because just about all the full-time faculty are well known in their field, you will learn a lot about what's trending in science, technology, health, just about anything
-It's nice to be a part of an organization committed to its community.  During crisis NYU has a lot of resources to help you or ways you can volunteer to help your community
-Good work/life balance. Lots of time off compared to other industries
-NYU is truly a community.  You will really feel like part of a family.
cons:
-Many in management have been there forever and are stuck in their ways and unwilling to change.  Not enough management learning leadership skills. 
-There's not enough incentive to work hard, so the longer the employee stays at the organization the more they start to get complacent.  You will do all the work as a new employee.
-Even though it's a learning institution, you will be surprised at how much the management doesn't follow basic management and leadership principles.  Unorganized.
-Lots of busy work to fill the day with no thoughtful direction or long term goals
-Like any big organization, each school/dept is different so everyone's experience is slightly different, but when there's bad leadership it can be a very toxic environment for everyone. I'm sure that applies to any job.  
-Extremely political.  You have to know how to navigate the political climate at NYU or you will have a hard time receiving promotions and gaining recognized for your accomplishments.
-Below industry pay

review_title: Young, fast paced environment with ample opportunity to learn and grow , Good place to work, excellent professors
job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Young, fast paced environment with ample opportunity to learn and grow. Such a great place to own your career, set your parameters and develop a network. Smart people and endless resources.Great expense policy. Free meals, parking, mileage, coffee, professional dues, tuition.
cons: The hours can become long, but you can work from anywhere. During busy season some people show up around 9am and work until 9pm, while others work 7-7pm depending on your preference. Of course, your schedule depends on the clients to which you're assigned.

job_title: IT Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Super chill job and not too demanding. Lots of little perks like free food now and then (there are many meetings). Learn to manage a lot of responsibility and your time as well.
cons: Sometimes there is little to no work to do during the 'quiet' days. Some might say this is a pro... But it can get boring at times.

review_title: Growth opportunity depends where you work
job_title: Social Media Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity to work on unique projects, a well-known institution that will certainly draw attention on your resume, generous vacation time
cons: A ridiculous back pay policy, opportunity to advance is based on where you work at the institution

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, great vacation, access to a broad array of services available to the NYU community.  Values putting the student first and creates a divers, inclusive environment.
cons: Non-profit organization that tries to operate as a for-profit.  Collective bargaining agreements create a culture of mediocrity in a lot of the administrative/student services departments. Organization is extremely fragmented; each school operates as a separate entity which makes sharing best practices very difficult and creates a very isolated environment. Extremely hierarchical and bureaucratic organization that is not very agile.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It's awesome to live in the city and get to teach.  NYU is located in a cool neighborhood and has high quality academic resources.  The professors are usually pretty interesting people doing cool research.
cons: Students not very enthusiastic about learning.  Some students are very bright, but most do not seem like they want to be in the classroom.  There is a large discrepancy in how much TA's are paid by department from reasonably decent to next to nothing.  No dental or vision benefits either.

review_title: Good part-time job to build resume
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros:
- Good pay for the hour
- Adjuncts are unionized, so you'll get some benefits and protection
- Professional development fund for adjuncts ($1,000 a year)
- Subsidized insurance after three semesters 
- Overall cool and helpful colleagues
- Great coordinators
- Mostly great students
- Ability to be creative and design curriculum
- Huge semester breaks
- Looks good on resume for the first part of your career and staying for two years will give you a lot of exit options
- Great job for a grad student
- Access to awesome resources at NYU, plus discounted tickets to movies and plays
- You can get a lot of work
cons:
- No real room to move up, full-time positions only open up sporadically
- No guarantee you'll be promoted to full-time and many teachers have been adjuncts for 10+ years
- Full-time lecturers have anemic salaries, so even making full-time doesn't provide a big pay boost.  If you've been teaching a lot (20 hours/week), you might even take a pay-cut.
- Inflexible enrollment dates for health insurance, so you may have to wait close to two years until it kicks in.  Plus, you still have to pay about $200/mo for it.
- If you teach three sections per semester (Spring, Fall, Summer) at 16 contact hours per week, you'll probably still make under $50,000/year
- Teaching in an intensive setting can be exhausting.  You'll get a lot of time off, but your time "on" will be very demanding.
- As mentioned in "Pros," huge breaks...that are unpaid (the con).  No paid vacation at all.
- You have to reschedule any classes you cancel.  There are no allotted sick days and you cannot get someone to substitute unless you're hospitalized or on jury duty.
- Adjunct "track" in general is pretty tough, as universities are increasingly relying on adjuncts and part-time/contract staff.  I would not recommend getting sucked into this.
- As mentioned in "Pros," you can get a lot of work...but adjuncts are basically used as full-time staff minus the benefits (the con).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great environment. Great benefits. Nice and friendly co-workers. The work in general is not so stressful. And the location is great, convenient to everything.
cons: Not really much downsides. In my position specifically, the downside is you get a lot on your plate that sometimes it is a little bit overwhelming. Also everyone around you is hardworking, which can also be considered as one of the 'cons'. LOL

review_title: Not very time-consuming; payment structure could be better
job_title: Teaching Assistant and Instructor in New York, NY
pros:
1. Not very time-consuming to prepare and teach the classes.
2. Students are smart.
cons:
1. Currently it's a flat payment, meaning that you get the same amount regardless of it's a 100-student class or 10-student class. This could be a problem for a large class.

2. Payment is on the low end, compared with other universities and with the high tuition fee collected by NYU every year.

review_title: Good pay, great benefits, stressful work environment
job_title: International Student Advisor in New York, NY
pros: NYU pays well in comparison to other institutions, however, you definitely work for your salary. Their benefits are also very good, particularly their retirement matching, tuition remission, and maternity leave!
cons: Many of the offices are stressful to work in and the work is often never ending. Expectations are high and work/life balance can be difficult to manage during certain times of the year.

review_title: The NYU School of Law gave me the opportunity to grow in my career and discover what I'm truly passionate about.
job_title: Editorial Assistant in Auckland, Auckland
pros: NYU School of Law's culture is supportive and comfortable.  The University offers great benefits, continuing education reimbursement and opportunities for growth.
cons: The University does not always work as a whole and instead acts as separate entities (eg - law school, business school, etc).  This makes it easier for management, but isn't always beneficial to the students.

job_title: Researcher in New York, NY
pros: Location is as good as you could hope for in the middle of Manhattan. Brand name is getting better. If you do a good job, your references will be a lot better than the generic reference. A lot of the faculty are distinguished in their fields (Economics)
cons: Professors are not all interested in working with unproven students.

review_title: Still prevails the white man at the top leadership positions.
job_title: Budget Analyst in New York, NY
pros: I joined NYU for the tuition remission.
cons: People have big egos, lots of politics, passive/aggressive behavior, bullying from the top down. Many people working there has biases against many minorities groups. Everything happens under cover nothing is overt.

review_title: Adjunct Graduate Instructor as a MFA Candidate in Creative Writing
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: You can make good connections with important people of the creative writing community. You get to teach undergrads and if you get someone to observe you teach they will write you a letter of recommendation. You can make your own syllabus and create a reading list/packet. There is no required reading.
cons: The pay is not terrific and NYU is expensive. The students are spoiled-rich kids. There is very little training in the way of teaching.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I was offered a position for Teaching Assistant at the end of my first semester. My pay per hour increased from the first year to the second. It is a great place for opportunities, great people to lear from, very flexible, but is expected a good job and on time.
cons: The only negative part is the total number of students you have per class. Sometimes, there is only one TA for a class of over 60 students with very long homework every week. You will be doing overtime to finish the job.

review_title: Working part-time as a preceptor (teaching assistant) is enjoyable and rewarding.
job_title: Preceptor in New York, NY
pros: The courses are great, so there is opportunity to learn as you teach. If you have a helpful lecturer (as I have), the entire experience can be really fun too. Many of the students are bright and well-prepared.
cons: Although my work hours are supposedly limited to 20 hours per week (part time), I have found that much more time is required to complete the work required. This is mainly because I'm preceptor for a reading-intensive course, so more technical courses may be easier.

review_title: New York University is a great place to work.
job_title: University Administration in New York, NY
pros: You have the opportunity to work for a leading global organization with competitive salaries and fantastic benefits.  The University is very diverse and there are many different kinds of positions for people with a myriad of talents and experiences.  It is a small city and the connections to smart and interesting people abound.  If you take advantage there are numerous chances for cultural and educational enrichment.
cons: Like any large organization, it is big.  One must have the tolerance for dealing with complexity in processes and politics.

review_title: NYU Employee for 10 years in different departments
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros:
* Supportive and casual work environment
* Good work/life balance
* Great benefits and excellent vacation time
* Exciting to be part of a changing institution
cons:
* Many of the departments are small, which can mean limited options for growth within a single department
* Work is not always challenging--can be very administrative 
* Department might be doing things in an archaic way and could be resistant to change
* Management is often pulled in different directions and spends little time overseeing staff
