job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros:
The faculty and administration at NYU truly are driven by research so working in research at the University has been a pleasure. The focus is on acquiring massive grants, conducting top-level research, and producing quality papers.
From my experience, Principal Investigators have been willing to provide training while allowing green researcher and research assistants to learn on the job.
And leadership opportunities are always present.
cons:
The quality of research papers is indeed high, but the desired quantity is also quite high. Given this, the quality is sometimes somewhat sacrificed so that additional research projects can be pushed through rapidly.
Also, with a strong focus on research, I have noticed that, for some professors, students and classes are secondary because those professors are primarily researchers who have to teach classes so that they are able to continue conducting their research. It is a trade off with which any college/ university constantly struggles.
Additionally, working in such a large university becomes difficult when collaboration between separate departments is required. Different technological systems in addition to varying schedules and course point systems create constant issues. Unfortunately, NYU is a very decentralized university due to its size. There is simply no way for the entire university to be run by one group and work on the same schedule and through the same technological systems. Different departments have to be separated and run as separate colleges for the overall university to keep moving. The sacrifice is a lack of cohesiveness among those separated departments. Often times, one hand does not know what the other is doing and that creates logistical and administrative issues.

job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros: Great student life. Teaching is fun and optional for PhD's. The University is great with grants and travel allowances. The offices are great too.
cons: The hours are brutal (as in all PhD's), life in NYC on a grad student budget can be hard. Academic life can get a little monotonous at times, and after NYU it's hard to find a job in a more interesting place.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Great school but that’s where it ends. I worked on the administrative side and it was the worst experience of my 20 year professional life. The only pro was the great coworkers I had around to commiserate with in an effort to make it through the day without breaking down.
cons: On a macro level, Finance, Operations & Treasury Division will destroy your soul and any positivity you may have. On an even more micro level within FO&T, the Controllers Division is even more of a nightmare. Stay away.

review_title: Great place to work, salary makes it hard to support a family in NYC
job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: NYU provides a supportive atmosphere, job security, and an environment that is full of life (it is enegizing to be around students).  There tends to be a lot of down time, so it is easy to catch your breath (and check Facebook).
cons: This is education, so the salaries are not very high.

review_title: More corporate than it used to be
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, including deeply discounted education, generous vacation and retirement, and, in some roles, flexible work arrangements.
cons: The corporate world has taken over academia. It's now much more of a traditional business environment than it is one of learning and exploration.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: The salary is good for teaching students but the treatment by the university is very unfair and rude.  They don't care about their employees or the qualifications of candidates at times
cons: If you are not on the good side of the big wigs then consider yourself screwed. They are very unfair. They only like to hire unqualified friend or they hire over qualified individuals that are in need of a job for very little pay

review_title: Great working atmosphere & learning experience & the nicest, classiest, most collegial people I've ever worked with.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Opportunities to learn, do new things, be mentored, and grow professionally. Excellent benefits & outstanding work/life balance. Long-term job security. I rate the people as A+.  They are the nicest, classiest group of people I've ever worked with. Very collegial atmosphere.
cons: While benefits such as retirement account and vacation time are superb, base salaries can be very low compared to the for-profit world. It can take a very long time for management to acknowledge that your accomplishments merit a promotion.

job_title: Student Technician in New York, NY
pros: The job is mostly low-key, save for busier times of the semester. After your regular maintenance work is done in the studios, you have time to read manuals, experiment with equipment, learn to make your own cables. Though, as long as you look busy with something related to the job, you're good. :-)
cons: Your bosses are a bit tyrannical, but are generally nice guys (and they are freaking geniuses to boot - they know their stuff). Don't get on their bad side by slacking, or you will not like them very much.

job_title: Rock Wall Attendant in New York, NY
pros: I had wonderful experiences with many of my coworkers. The scheduling was fairly flexible. And the work itself wasn't particularly strenuous.
cons: My managers were cocky and egotistical, especially considering they had no knowledge of what I was expected to be at least proficient in. When I asked about a specific policy or how to do anything in particular, I was always referred to a coworker.

job_title: Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Famous one at New York. Good at many services and wold class faculty members. Great location in New York comparing with Columbia Unv.
cons:
Cheap and bureaucratic:
The faculty has to pay for the gym right at the basement of engineering school, which is free to employees before merging with NYU.  Tuition remission is announced in benefit, but it is actually a fake since no faculty member is eligible to credit bearing tuition remission.

job_title: Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Employees and management are kind and helpful. In my experience as a Tisch administration assistant, my boss looked out for me in every aspect.
cons: Perhaps this is simply a symptom of administrative work, but the tasks were inherently inefficient and could benefit from streamlining.

review_title: As a support staff member at NYU, I notice that this educational institution behaves more like a corporate company.
job_title: Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Decent colleagues. NYU generally hires smart, interesting people. Decent salary and benefits. Nice to work in the West Village neighborhood.
cons: The educational institution behaves like a fortune 500 company. Working environments and office cultures can vary to great degrees. There is a vast difference in treatment when comparing upper management to lower staff. Upper management does not promote mentorship, or growth experiences.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
- location in New York
- vibrant campus with excellent faculty
- connections to other universities close-by such as CUNY, Columbia and Cornell
cons:
- The expensive living situation is hard to manage on an academic salary
- NYU has an extremely bureaucratic administration, which sometimes makes getting things done quite difficult.

job_title: Monographs Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Supervisors are helpful and their guidance allows you to learn the job well. They are open to helping you whenever you need so don't feel shy to ask because you want the job to be done properly the first time so they don't have to fix your mistakes later. Greg Ferguson is also great, and he takes the time to learn all the work study students' names.
cons: If you are a student, make sure to let them know of shift conflicts when it is around exam time, need to let them ahead of time.

review_title: NYU is a great place to work
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Competitive salary with nice benefits such as health insurance, paid bonding leave for new children, pre-tax metrocard purchasing, and tuition remission.
cons: It's a big university and it would be easy to feel like a number.  This depends on the department you work in of course.  Sometimes, it can be difficult to get your foot in the door here, but that also means that once you do, internally moving up or across to other jobs is easier which is nice for mobility.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The people are all really great to work with, which makes shifts more enjoyable to work. They are very accommodating to student schedules. It's always easy to get someone to cover shifts if something comes up.
cons: Patrons can be really frustrating to deal with. Hours are inconsistent and scheduling process is rather chaotic, especially now that the system has changed.

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros:
- Work-life balance
- Tuition remission for full-time employees
- Extremely friendly coworkers
- Collaborative, congenial culture
- Approachability of administrators at all levels of hierarchy
- Reasonable pay for a non-profit
- Great health, dental, vision, gym benefits
cons:
- Limited opportunities for career growth (someone above you has to quit, move or die)
- Limited salary growth trajectory
- Faculty can be prickly and difficult to work with
- Limited paternity leave
- Competition with Ivy and other elite schools without comparable resources/endowment

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The benefits of living and working in New York City are incalculable and provide a stimulating environment and opportunities of many sorts for both faculty and students
cons: The university is large and the corporate culture lacks compassion. Decisions are made by the administration in an often high handed manner and without much consultation with the faculty of individual schools.

review_title: Great place to work at, very diverse and enriching experiences.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Globally connected, open and diverse. The university has a well designed system of managing its resources and activities. Many of the world leading scholars work at NYU and they contribute a lot to making it a welcoming place.
cons: Too many good activities and so little time to focus on research. This is not really a con per se but it is hard to resist the many tempting events taking place on campus.

review_title: NYU IT OTSS is a great opportunity
job_title: UI-Ux Developer in New York, NY
pros: NYU OTSS provides a great working environment especially if you are a current student. It serves as a fantastic opportunity for networking and as a launching point for your career.
cons: There is sometimes a lack of organization that might not be the best if you are interested in future career opportunities at this employer. There is a lot of turnover that can make dealing with management and product owners difficult.

review_title: Pretty good place to work but lots of room to improve
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros:
NYU employees get excellent benefits: 22 days off, plus university closes for winter break, retirement matching plan, tuition remission, etc.
Good location
Nice people
cons: Work life balance can be challenging, very little transparency, hard to move up unless you switch departments, low salaries, unskilled managers,  favoritism. HR is useless.  Parental leave could be better.

job_title: Department Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission makes the job worthwhile if going back to school. They have decent benefits though they've decreased in recent years.
cons: There is an inherent lack of training and communication among upper level leadership and mid level managers and employees. New policies are implemented without being announced and there is often a lack of training or access to training needed to perform job.

review_title: NYU is an exceptional place to work.
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Accessibility of faculty, senior management.  Interest in students and their success.  academic rigor is high across the various schools.  The undergraduate program is quite good.
cons: Sometimes difficult to correct errors when they are made.   Some faculty seem to have perception that having a union protects all behavior of staff.

review_title: Great overall training for postdocs, but not good practice of research groups
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in New York, NY
pros: The Postdoc Office of NYU provides multiple opportunities to improve all sort of useful capabilities for postdocs from writing to project management. NYU also offers great support for pattens and entrepreneurial adventures. There is an overwhelming number of interesting seminars weekly and multiple opportunities for collaborations.
cons: The University and departments do not offer a good protection for postdocs in the research groups. Bad practices are tolerated due to the permanent position of professors. Researchers with a visa are particularly vulnerable in this situation.

job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros:
1) Tuition benefits are great
2) Lots of new initiatives and improvements continuously
cons:
1) Salary is low across the board
2) Which school/department you work out matters a lot
3) Not a lot of career growth opportunity, despite the size of the university
4) No real network feel among employees
5) Turnover is either extremely high or extremely low...some people stay at the same admin role for decades...others are viewed as stable if they stay until they get their degree

review_title: Highly Decentralized - Your Experience May Vary
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits especially for retirement.
cons: Lack of transparency of management and executives; very hierarchy-oriented; depending on the immediate supervisor, there may be limited opportunity to grow, expand skills, or potential for promotion; no longer a place for long-term security at the administrative level. Again, depending on the department, the environment can be indifferent and sometimes toxic.

review_title: Decent working environment, but the pay and benefits are low compared to other universities
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Great students, some great faculty members,  near lots of public transportation.
cons:
Pay and benefits are much lower than other universities for which I've worked.  I've heard it's very hard to get on the tenure track. 

Also....NYU is taking over the east village and doesn't care who they displace in the process.  It was hard to reconcile my dislike of this aggressive expansion and my enjoyment of teaching there.

job_title: Technical Support in New York, NY
pros: It is great to work for new york university technical support. The best part is that you have freedom to do what you want while on the Job since you have to walk to location of the pc repair.
cons: This job could pay more. it is a little difficult to advance to an upper position. you do not get to have an office just for you since its shared with the other technicians.

job_title: Academic Advisor/Tisch Drama in New York, NY
pros: NYU is a good employer, which provides great benefits to their employees.  There are many options for professional development.
cons: The Department of Drama has had a lot of 'turnover' recently.  The salaries are low and there isn't room for growth as an Advisor.  The current model of the Student Services Team does not allow for longevity of staff.  This is a disservice to the students.

review_title: Fun and lots of freedom - good as adjuncting goes
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros:
- freedom to design your own syllabus and lesson plans, choose your own materials
- competitive pay
cons:
- no health insurance until you've worked there a year and a half
- never know until the day before the semester starts what you'll be teaching, or if you'll be teaching at all
- only paid for student-facing time, not the time you spend planning and marking
...all the adjunct problems.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brooklyn, NY
pros: This school within the University has an extremely supportive environment and supervision.  It is open to new ideas and discussion of new initiatives, and is very committed to training and career advancement.
cons: Service and administrative departments across the university are not well aligned.  Much time is spent (and re-spent) on the "basics," as they differ from one department to the next.  The school where I work is very open to new ideas, but my co-workers in allied departments across the University may not be.

job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
-Be hired as a student in multiple offices (admissions in my case)
-Pick your own work schedule, with hours around your classes, with minimum weekly hours
-Can possibly continue working through all 4 years in school
-Can be promoted
-Minimum wage in NYU is being raised
cons:
-Work can be tedious, repetitive, or monotonous depending on which office you work at
-In admissions its all paperwork
-Not much exploration or opportunity to expand responsibility or grow

job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I get paid well, at least when compared to many of my friends working for other departments. But at the same time, there are jobs that don't pay you well.
cons: Not much to learn. You are stuck to your job list and that is it. Like any other MNC, you do not get to explore and learn all that you are interested in.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Decent Work/Life balance, compensation, time off.
cons: Only people with advanced degrees can rise to upper level administration. Advanced degrees are understandable if one is working to expand the boundaries in a particular field. Administration does NOT serve this role. It is management. It is no wonder that upperlevel administration has become so bloated and beurocratic because they are overlooking managers with real world experience while favoring inexperienced intellectuals with the right pedigrees.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
-As an international student at NYU, if you find an on-campus job, you don't need CPT in order to work. 
-Most teachers that you work for are nice and considerate. 
-Sometimes you can enjoy free foods offered by the department you work for.
-You can meet many new friends.
cons: -Some teachers have high requirements for teaching assistants, so it is possible that you have to be on campus for four days a week and leave in the evening. It really depends on if your teacher is nice.

job_title: America Reads Tutor in New York, NY
pros: NYU gives students several opportunities to make a difference with their America Reads program.  Their pay, support, and training are superb.
cons: Management is invisible and due to the size of the university it can become difficult to stand out from your peers and speak to management.

review_title: Academic setting, great benefits, nice people
job_title: Junior Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros:
Great benefits: health, dental, commuter, tuition remission.
Many holiday days and university holidays.
No strict dress code (depends on the department).
Relaxed academic setting.
Good work-life balance, short work days.
Upper management supportive, collaborative, and nice.
Colleagues are usually young when compared to large organizations.
Free shuttle buses around the city.
cons: Limited growth opportunities. No bonuses. Many administrative personnel to deal with. The hospital and dental facilities are located in the less attractive areas of the city and lack subway access (along 1st ave.)

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Great for entry level, and for building connections. Flexible with scheduling. Benefits depend on which department you're in, but overall they're fair.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic work environment, simple day to day processes can become incredibly challenging because of red tape and procedures that are ultimately unnecessary.

review_title: Tuition Remission will be your best friend
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
*Great place to network and meet folks from all walks of life
* Furthering your education is highly encouraged (tuition remission helps!)
*Awesome health and dental benefits + you qualify for a free pension plan after 1 year of working
cons:
*Bureaucracy is real and exists across 90% of the institution
*No bonuses or salary increases  - your best bet is to switch to another position within the university for hopefully higher pay

review_title: Great place to work, if you can land a job there
job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great people, good compensation, amazing location, very competent and enthusiastic co-workers, friendly working environment
cons: It's very hard to get into the system- jobs are almost always recruited internally. Not very open to people from outside the university network.

review_title: Good for parents and tuition remission but less rewarding for the in-betweens
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: humane! 7 hour work days, lots of vacation and generally great coworkers
cons: a structured advancement process that rewards time rather than performance. great for parents for work/life balance and 90-100% tuition remission but for others less incentive to stay after the work becomes routine.

review_title: Very Competitive but also supportive, environment.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Wide Neuroscience presence, from systems to molecular biology to genetics approaches, from pure theoretical work to invertebrates to rodents to monkeys to humans (FMRI)
cons: Extremely competitive environment. Bad weather through out the year. Salaries are not scaled to the city costs by default. City life and the cons of it.

review_title: Great place to build a career
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Great university which is always striving to be better.  The benefits and resources of the university are very strong.
cons: Concerns about long term strength of the university.  Needs to focus on quality and invest more in downtown campus.  Power concentrated in a very small number of people and many decisions are made behind closed doors.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Very good academic infrastructure and atmosphere; falcuty and administrative staff are all very nice and helfpful. Your work can be appreciated.
cons: There are not a lot of opportunities to reach out to the industry. If there are more chances to interact with the industry you are researching about it will be much better.

job_title: Research Scholar in New York, NY
pros: My work is very flexible and I get to spend time on interesting projects. Because I'm a research scholar (which is a particular type of appointment) I have a lot of flexibility in how I spend my time.
cons: The bureaucracy is labyrinthine and unhelpful. I frequently struggle with simple vendor payments or with reimbursements for legitimate work related expenses.

job_title: Research Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros: very great environment to work at.  you meet a lot of great people here and it is also a great way to network with peers from your own school.
cons: very big and spread out school. The city is very big so even though it sounds attractive you can sometimes get lost in it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Pro's include being in new york city, a young faculty with opportunity to do research you feel is good, a great support system and very nice laboratories.
cons: Amount of Grant money needs to increase.... Furthurmore, I believe the school needs to be more selective in their candidates and Students.

review_title: Great  Institution to work for.        President Sexton is AWESOME... Higher Learning at it finest. GLOCAL ON THE SQUARE
job_title: MEDIA TECH (Senior) in New York, NY
pros: Great place to learn, grow & become a productive member of society while getting paid to do something you love.  (If you're that type of person) (knowledge everywhere)
cons:
A few rotten apples but 90% are dedicated & focused professional.  
If you just want just $$$ you will be miserable...

review_title: Great benefits, culture slow to change.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Taking classes for free or a discount is a great benefit. Health insurance was very good as well. Work hours are about as low as modern day allows.
cons: Worked in the technology department. Both the business side and our own team were very slow to adapt.  Projects took forever to complete. Culture is mixed. There were some laid-back types who were there probably due to the job being less demanding, but many people are very hierarchical and like to 'pull rank.'

review_title: As an Adjunct Instructor at NYU School of Professional Studies
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: NYU has a wonderful brand so there is a "wow" factor in having this assignment
cons:
SPS Program Management/Administration has recently (mid-2015) changed hands so hopefully, is on its way to much needed improvement
Room assignments! Courses for working professionals are frequently taught in high school classrooms which diminishes the "wow" factor
Poor communication to adjunct instructor staff about program and course changes which we end up finding out from the students (!)

job_title: Graduate Assistant Non Teaching in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits - there are many projects to be involved in if you’re interested
cons: Office politics? ( you could be doing all the work but if you’re not the kind of person to show off during meetings, and speak enthusiastically about what you’re working on, others will take credit for your work).. This puts non native english speakers at a disadvantage because they might not be able to articulate their thoughts or speak eloquently about their work as much as native English speakers would.

job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Working in a work study position was nice because it was flexible (they worked around my class schedule) and they were patient with me learning new skills
cons: The staff and my supervisors were patronizing and expected me to complete personal errands for them.  The work they gave wasn't engaging or challenging, just stuff they didn't want to complete on their own.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in New York, NY
pros: You get a paycheck. The coworkers are wonderful. Benefits are nice. You get really good training. They just reassessed the salaries so it's fair.
cons: They treat you like you're just a cog. management ignores your needs. bad attitudes in the work place. You will not be treated like a human being. They don't care about your work/life balance

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Great energy at NYU and as an adjunct, there is the ability to continue learning while teaching and mentoring the next generation of leaders.
cons: As with adjunct positions elsewhere, the pay is low considering all the hours of preparation and follow-up for each class session.   Getting curriculum development compensation for developing a class or adapting a class for online or blended learning is a challenge.

review_title: I highly recommend working at NYU.
job_title: Payrool Clerk in New York, NY
pros:
I have very flexible hours because it is a work-study position.
The NYU office setting is very friendly. Furthermore, NYU corporate structure is very internally organized.
cons: During the academic there is an excess of work. During the non-academic months there is sometimes a need to temporarily change divisions.

job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: Great health care, access to library, and excellent campus location. They also send out regular career advancement courses, but be aware that tuition remission does not equal free.
cons: There is not a lot of room for individual compensation based on merit since you are paid by your grade. This means that you could be an excellent employee, but you are not eligible for bonuses or raise. You will also receive emails asking for donations for scholarships, which is appalling considering how much the tuition is.

job_title: Nursing Student in New York, NY
pros: The nursing college is new and it has a lot of up to date resources for the students to take advantage of.
cons: The nursing college is a big complex system that sometimes loses sight of or is simply not able to cater to the individual needs of its students.

review_title: NYU is a great place to work for those who want to go back to school.
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission for many degree and non-degree programs without an extended work commitment. Great location in downtown NYC. Intelligent and motivated colleagues.  Good benefits.
cons: Salaries are lower in an academic/nonprofit setting, compared to other jobs of the same caliber at corporate workplaces.  Smaller departments (compared to corporate environments) and unions may make it difficult to advance quickly and/or at regular intervals.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Good resources,  project and professor for research.  lots of opportunity to communicate with world leading scientist.  lots of discount ticket for show, movies.
cons: living is far too expensive as a postdoc in NYC.  You can not support your family in any way.  Commute is a disaster.

review_title: One of the best Educational Institutions to Work.
job_title: Production Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Overall, I was very satisfied working in post production at NYU.  The salary was good and the people were very supportive for the most part.
cons: Most of the really long term employees did not appear too happy.  It made me think about other opportunities after a certain amount if time with NYU.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY
pros: You will make contacts in the NYU administration that can help you academically.
cons: They will exploit and take advantage of overqualified international students to fill $10/hr positions. They know they are getting a bargain. International students are left with one option in their first 2 semesters, work on campus, or don't work. Unfortunately there are only a few jobs that pay more than $10 per hour. International students, prepare to work for someone who has less education and experience than you. Demeaning experience.

review_title: The workflow was well-balanced. I enjoyed working on the team. It was small and the burden was evenly shared.
job_title: Graduate Student Academic Program Officer in New York, NY
pros: Great team that was always willing to help. I felt comfortable asking questions. There was of course an hierarchy in the office but this was not overbearing.
cons: The pay but got a raise! Another con at first was being asked to attend meetings but not being expected to speak or even take notes. So, sitting in meetings just to observe is a bit awkward.

review_title: Very low pay, but a great place to get started in NYC and higher education
job_title: Student Life Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: I worked directly with the students and I had a blast working with such a smart, successful group.  My coworkers were great and high-energy, and the benefits were good.  Helpful to have NYU on your resume if you're planning to continue on in higher education.
cons: Low pay and not much room for advancement.  If you live in a cheaper neighborhood, the commute in isn't easy.

review_title: Work-Study program at the Admissions Office
job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: I worked at the Office of Admissions at the School of Professional Studies at New York University while I was a sophomore. The office environment was very easy-going and my supervisor, Jeb, was awesome. I did filing work and data entry on Fridays.
cons: The pay was low, but then I wasn't doing heavy-duty administrative work. I knew what I was getting into and it was nice to work-study as part of my financial aid package.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, especially tuition remission. Lot of smart people around (although sometimes you have to find them ... after all academics are a curious bunch). Flexibility, and freedom to work on interesting projects.
cons: Salaries are comparatively low to industry standards. Not always the most efficient environment to get things done (again, academics ... they like to _really_ discuss things)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Amazing faculty, world-class research, collaborations with all of NYC institutions
cons: Too much bureaucracy, faulty and students have lower priority than institution making money

review_title: NYU is a fantastic place to work - full of opportunities to grow, energetic environment, and generous benefits.
job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: Strong salary especially for entry-level positions (more than expected in many cases); benefits including long winter break vaction; variety of departments to work for.
cons: There are many NYU systems to learn in a short amount of time, which can be overwhelming. Oftentimes you will have to submit requests and go through a lot of paperwork before you can get a simple task completed.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
-Benefits/ Work life balance
-Employees are for the most part friendly
-Intelligent group of people - who for the most part are willing to share their knowledge
Opportunities are available if you work hard, network, and push. Be relentless.
-Hire from within
-Opportunity to go to school almost free of charge.
cons: -The pay is not the greatest BUT the benefits make up for it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
- Competitive stipend compared with other graduate programs. 
- Comprehensive health care benefits.
- Washington Square Campus is in a great location.
- Access to a lot of opportunities outside academia.
- Teaching positions are optional and pay extra.
- Great advisors!
cons:
- Perks about being in very fun/interesting NYC can backfire and make it difficult to be productive.
- Many cases where grad students are accidentally over payed and expected to return that money. 
- Bureaucratic measures can sometimes feel ill-defined.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are exceptional -- I don't use the medical, but dental is free, and tuition remission is almost 100%.
cons: NYU is extremely hierarchical; senior leadership is not well connected to or tuned into needs of other administrators.  It is also large and organizationally very decentralized: administrative systems do not work well together.

job_title: Research Assistant, Instructor in New York, NY
pros:
Convenient, fun place.
very good academic environment.
Compensation is enough to live in the city.
Have many good chances to get into big companies.
cons:
No dorms.
The offices in the buildings are quite depressing.
Not many extra curriculum, activities because the school is right in the center of the city.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The vacation retirement benefits are good and the work-life balance is fairly flexible, which almost makes up for the the frustration of working here and the lower salary.
cons: The salary is not great and the bureaucracy of the organization makes if it very difficult to do good work. They don't seem to value anyone but tenured faculty

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: Generous benefits, interesting work, collegial atmosphere
cons: Lack of opportunities for advancement - i.e., promotions are very difficult to come by, even for employees that deserve one. It seems that the only way to advance within the organization would be for folks to leave. In some cases, this is next to impossible, as there are folks who've been here for more than 20 years occupying director-level and higher positions that younger employees may aspire to.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Students coworkers are generally amicable. Catered food every few weeks. Given help from Facilities to to customize workspace.
cons: Red tape associated with any highly bureaucratic institutions. Idea for increasing team productivity, making program operations more efficient, and promoting program said "no" to 7/10 times. High turnaround of student workers stunts program development.

review_title: Working with young adults and teenagers here was a very enriching experience for not only the students, but I as well.
job_title: Academic Tutor in New York, NY
pros: The faculty treat you like family and if you ever have an issue, there is always a location to go or someone to talk to. The pay was perfect for the level we were at.
cons: Honestly the hardest challenge was probably making sure the students were understanding everything. Everyone learns differently. But adapting to this was not very difficult.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: good environment. People there are very nice. It is in New York and NYU is a very good school. Life easy is easy if you are not ambitious.
cons: salary is not good. Management is not good. Work demanding is high. There is no such big promotion. It is good to get experience over there.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: My supervisor is very kind and prompt in helping me. The atmosphere is absolutely relaxed and everybody is very respectful. I can be flexible with my working schedule.
cons: The music faculty is very big and so, for this reason, it is hard to organize some make-up lessons. However, there are much more pros than cons

job_title: Residence Hall Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros:
Good benefits
Free housing
Working with students
Free meals
Flexible schedule sometime
Flexible time and support for higher education while working
Some flexibility and freedom with curriculum and workshop development
cons:
Long hours
Duty rotation
Some elements of a corporate bureaucracy and competition that are framed as a warm, welcoming, inclusive atmosphere
Diversity and workplace parity issues that are addressed by leadership in name only in some circumstances if at all
Un level playing field for promotions and leadership
Culture of conformity rather than innovation in many circumstances

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: NYU has great benefits -- health, dental, vision, retirement (and they contribute to your retirement), ample vacation time. Depends on department but co-workers are smart, fun, etc.
cons: Salaries at SCPS are low. Decisions are made at the top-level with little to no input from staff/faculty. Feels like working in "business" not "education". Not a lot of innovation. Lots of layoffs of long-term employees. No professional development opportunities

review_title: The best paid job you can get
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
As it says, 
This is the job where you get 20 bucks an hour as a graduate teaching assistant. Most other jobs in the univ offer around 10 bucks.
Being a graduate assistant, you also get to learn a lot since you have to be prepared to help the undergrad students with their education.
cons:
They overwork you at times.
It isn't a permanent job. You can only work during the fall and spring semesters.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: This is the best place I've ever worked! For such a large institution, extraordinary efforts are made to create a sense of community and connection among faculty and staff.  I have all the tools necessary to do my job well.  There are many perks and discounts available locally just for being and NYU employee.  Very progressive policies and practices. Great place to work!
cons: Benefits are a bit expensive, especially for families.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Well respected University with a plethora of resources allowing for opportunity to succeed. Great location and excellent neighborhood
cons: Cost of living in New York on a low salary for  your skill set  does not make it an enticing option for individuals holding a doctorate degree.

review_title: NYU is in the HR dark ages
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are great. Most of your co-workers will be decent people.
cons: When you are an admin aide or in the clerical union the university does not give you raises outside what is required by the contract. They also refuse to be flexible about schedules or time off. Especially Arts & Science. STAY AWAY. A&S is an Awful HR department. When the rest of the world is trying to work with employees to make them feel appreciated and offering flexible schedules it's like they are determined to make your life harder.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I would highly recommend any students at NYU, especially those in their freshman or sophomore years, to get a part-time job there. It's convenient, your colleagues are aware of your priorities as a student and you can easily schedule your shifts around those, and the pay is decent.
cons: I have no cons that I can immediately recall. Though bear in mind your experience working at NYU entirely depends on which department you are in.

job_title: GA/Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Working at NYU as a GA/Instructor was the best time I've had at a workplace...ever.  It far exceeded my expectations.
cons: The biggest CON I can think of is that Dojo closed.  Loved eating there...good and inexpensive food.  The business about John Sexton's votes of no confidence...I think a lot of muckrakers just want to be heard.

review_title: Treats Upper Management Like Gods, Poops on the Rest of Us
job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission, health care, 401B
cons: Poor work/life balance, long hours, abusive management, no job security.

job_title: IT Services Tech in New York, NY
pros: NYU looks out for your interests and is willing to help you if you have a problem. Although there is the whole bureaucracy, you get used to it, and it isn't that bad. Also working at the university, you can take many classes and use many of the university facilities which is great.
cons: It may take a while to move up at your place, but nonetheless you can, and the pay is good

job_title: Messenger/Transporter in New York, NY
pros: Okay pay/ great co-workers / room to grow with the proper title/ prestigious stepping stone in the medical field
cons: Management is disrespectful and lacks leadership qualities/ fails to understand the flaws with there management teams.

review_title: Review of NYU Graduate Assistant Position
job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY
pros: You need a job to enjoy life in New York City and while being a student in NYU, it really helps doing this on-campus job. It also offers health insurance waiver. Chance to develop yourself as a person.
cons: On-campus jobs are always temporary. And you need to look for another job towards the end of your studies here in the university.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Outstanding research-and-teaching venue that has greatly augmented its quality since I started a couple decades ago. It's in the heart of an incredibly diverse community in New York! Opportunities exist to contribute to the growth of unique global education initiatives. Good research support. Good benefits.
cons: It's in New York (grit, noise, high cost of living). Support mechanisms for research still need to be improved further. Benefits (e.g. health and dental insurance) could be improved further.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
-TAing here is great.  The load isn't too heavy, and the students are for the most part eager to learn.
-Pay and benefits are great (thanks UAW 2110!)
-the facilities are decent, a number of classrooms still use chalkboards instead of whiteboards, which is annoying.
-general campus facilities (library, gym, etc) are fantastic.
cons: -I've taught at 3 other colleges, and there's nothing specific to NYU that compares negatively with other schools, in my experience.

job_title: Public Safety Dispatcher in New York, NY
pros: Distinguished university setting is beneficial on resume.
cons: The security department has common sense policies and procedures on paper, but officers will boldly go against their duties. During my time there, officers refused to respond to fire alarms, fell asleep during their shifts (once during a suicide call at the officer's post), and generally failed to serve the student community. The dispatch office has been in an active construction zone for 2 years, with no end in sight. Upper management has little sway over the operations of security officers, citing the union for all their problems, and will do little to advocate on behalf of the department's dispatchers.

job_title: Software Developer in New York, NY
pros: Comfort place, helpful friends, elastic time conditions and elastic deadlines that does not make you feel bad or stressed .
cons: Not a big challenge is waiting for you in a campues working environment. Limited chance of getting higher positions in to your career which is not very good.

job_title: Project Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great people, environment, you could be exposed to great opportunities and work life balance. There would be people always willing to help you
cons: campus is too over crowded, there are too many departments that make it hard for you to take great chances of mvoing

review_title: Boring work and keep track of your own hours
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: on campus, fairly easy work, fairly flexible with your schedule and you can work as needed. some times there are hot girls that work there.
cons: pay isnt great, a lot of times they dont have the right hours of you working and you have to keep track of the email confirmations and bring it to their attention that you are not being paid accordingly

review_title: A relaxed environment driven by curiosity and quest for knowledge.
job_title: Digital Assets Manager in New York, NY
pros: The archives at the University are filled with some of the most interesting media stories increasing your knowledge and understanding of history tenfold. You will be in a stimulating and comfortable environment.
cons: the archives lack the necessary tools to increase efficiency. Little room for advancement. Friendly but weak management, which may have to do more with the funding, and inability to produce strategies to increase efficiency.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are great! Great location.
cons: Insecure and mediocre leadership. No room for growth. Manipulative and destructive leadership. No flex time; no work from home. Review of benefits in comparison to the work life culture at NYU is not worth it.

review_title: It started so well, but ended in tears.
job_title: Visiting Lecturer in New York, NY
pros: The university has an excellent academic reputation
cons: Academic staff are disposable commodities. You might as well be an Uber driver for all the respect you get from Deans and senior management

review_title: Don't Judge a Book by it's Cover
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: A great resume builder, very nice people to work with, bright students, excellent location(s), cutting edge courses to teach.
cons: Enormous universities like NYU come with the requisite political strife.  In the end, Adjuncts are just cogs in the vast machine that care about the bottom line (student "satisfaction") more than employee satisfaction.

job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Tremendous group of colleagues.   Diverse student body who are committed and strong academically.  New Dean that is very knowledgeable and effective in job.
cons: Non academic leadership is not very strong - seems misguided and distant from university and academic goals.

job_title: Graphic Designer in New York, NY
pros: I had the best boss of my life while I worked at NYU: kind, considerate, raised my pay without me even asking! Reasonable pay for part-time work, flexible hours.
cons: The only downside I can think of is that, as a student at the time, I wasn't allowed to work more hours.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY
pros: people, workculture is good, location is nice, many additional benefits are given such as free tuition, less work compared to corporates
cons: work is not challenging, people are not professional, a lot of work is adhoc and most of the times you are sitting empty and doing administrative tasks

job_title: Information Technology Specialist in New York, NY
pros: The hours are flexible and the work is not very demanding. It is a very comfortable job to have.
cons: No real promotion path, very low bonuses and raises. Salary goes up just by being here for decades...

job_title: VBC Events Assistant in New York, NY
pros: They are super accommodating of class schedules, my boss was amazing and the people I worked with were great too! I left because I graduated, but I am so lucky to have had this job during my time at NYU.
cons: It was a great place to work while I was a student, my boss took really good care of her employees. I don't have anything bad to say about working here.

review_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Center for Neural Science
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Excellent career-related resources (academic and non-academic), great working environment, outstanding work/life balance... perks of getting to live in the nicest area of one of the best cities in the world! The faculty here are incredible and the research is top-notch!! Truly one of the best places to do your postdoc
cons: None found yet, but I have only been here for a less than a year.

job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros:
Great Benefits - Really great!
Liberal atmosphere, with friendly co-workers.
Opportunities for education, if you can make the time. 
Fair vacation & sick leave policy.
cons:
Academics can have difficult personalities with which you have to deal on a regular basis.
I worked there for over a decade and never had opportunity for advancement, which I realize equally reflects upon myself.

review_title: A Graphic Designer creating emails and not design.
job_title: Graphic Designer in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Good employees, students and had some great events around the school.
cons: Bad and disfunctional management when it comes to creating design work. Not providing design projects. Emails, emails, emails. If your a true designer, don't go for this job because you will be sending emails all day long.

review_title: Part-time on campus work at NYU is a friendly environment
job_title: Media Assistant in New York, NY
pros: My part-time job working in the NYU Student Center is enjoyable. I work with friendly people and there is plenty of free time to do other work.
cons: My main concern about working at NYU is that the pay is not very competitive, and you cannot get as many hours as you would like.

review_title: fellowship recipient for PhD at Tandon (ECE)
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
- highly focused on research.
- not many required TA responsibilities
- professors pretty open to collaboration. especially across the river at the medical school
- department flexible for internships, etc. (note: more complicated for international students)
- MASSIVE desk compared to graduate student desk areas at other universities
- good connections with industry (NVIDIA, IBM, Verizon, and more)
cons:
- very few get their own office
- expensive to live in NYC

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: The people you work with are great. 35 hour work week gives you time for a life outside of work. Tuition remission benefit is the best. Vacation time is also a great benefit.
cons: Limited possibilities of moving up. Not great compensation.

job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Working at NYU was a breath of fresh air. I've worked at multiple institutions in the NYC area, and NYU was by far the best. Intellectual yet relaxed environment, and decent pay.
cons: I have no negatives to state about NYU. They offered me everything I wanted at the time, so I don't have any negatives

job_title: Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Bureaucracy will protect you. You will always have your check on time, benefits as promised, vacation days if you ask for them.
cons: Hard to move up unless you stay there for a long time. Not an ideal place for young people who want to do cutting edge work. They play it safe for better and worse.

job_title: Doctoral Student in New York, NY
pros: Living in New York City is nice, and location is pretty much the best thing going for NYU.  Compensation is adequate, benefits are fine.
cons:
The buracracy at NYU is insane, this place is entirely red tape. Was promised a five hundred dollar health care premium refund, but only received $8. NYU did nothing to intervene on behalf of all PhD students in this predicament. 
Education is put second to profit.

job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Benefit package is not too bad except for retirement plan (see cons), well-equipped university for doing research, very good for students
cons: Salary is not good enough for living New York, the communication with administrative staff is slow and often times noneffective, retirement plan when the company starts  contributions only at 2nd year and to keep them on your account you need to work at NYU for at least 3 years.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: In my experience NYU has been an excellent place to work because of it low stress work environment.
cons: The low stress environment also means that the money is not great either.

review_title: I was given the liberty to create and implement my ideas with the support from upper management.
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: NYU is a great collaborative work environment that has a surplus of great ideas.
cons: Do not have a good way of harnessing the pool of talented employees and skill set. Lacking project management professional

job_title: Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
extensive holiday time off.
Really no other pros. You would think that tuition remission would be a benefit, but as the university is a private university  you owe massive taxes that are deducted immediately from your paycheck.
cons:
No respect for staff or student body. Only care about faculty raises.
Anti-union. 
Major downsizing of staff with no compensation.
Overall, no interest in support staff morale in respect to work productivity.
No opportunity to grow for internal support staff.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: flexibility and easy work, easy to talk to any manager you want, have time for doing your own things. overall recommended
cons: not well paid as expected. environment need to be improved. No enough on-site facilities available, need to get more close space and cube

job_title: Director of Academic Development in New York, NY
pros: NYU Wagner is an entrepreneurial environment that allows staff to flex my leadership and management skills. Friendly staff and faculty.
cons: NYU is a large institution and university priorities are not always conveyed at the school level. HR support is largely automated at the university level.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: If you prefer doing very little work, then you will be happy at NYU. The administration is bloated an inefficient, so it can be a good place to waste time and collect a paycheck.
cons: NYU is an awful workplace for anyone with ambition or a strong commitment to quality work. Serving students is almost never a priority, and staff members are not rewarded in any predictable way for success.

job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: Great and generous benefits, diverse community, wonderful city.  SHC is closed from Christmas to New Years so it's essentially 6 weeks of vacation a year.
cons:
MAs are unionized but RNs are not. They can get away with murder. Work ethic is terrible. Makes work much more difficult for others because they can call out so much. 
No room for growth. Same mundane nursing care.

review_title: Rewarding Experience - Make a Difference in People's Lives
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros:
Make a difference in people's lives
Students who stay in touch through the years
Generally nice administrators
Flexibility to present courses the way you want
Reasonable pay for teaching hours
Being part of a world class organization
Helping to build a world class organization
cons:
For adjuncts, classes can be cancelled on very short notice and you don't get paid
People with personal agendas who push for control

job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Work-life balance, tuition reimbursement.  Not much else, the pay was well below market rate, and the raises each year was lower than the inflation rate.  So, technically, I lost money working here.
cons: Horrible old school mentality, awful leadership.  The CFO for whatever reason continues to shield directors who are awful at their jobs.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: great -- great environment, many different resources and support systems available. the university highly encourages side education and professional development.
cons: because of the scattered campus throughout the city, the entire university is fairly dis jointed and segmented. this leads to many different processes.

job_title: Resident Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The staff can be fun, depending on where your working, and I loved my coworkers. There is a real sense of community and some of the people are really great.
cons: There is always bureaucratic stuff, no matter where you go. Money goes to the wrong place and sometimes supervisors are incompetent. Lots of catty colleagues and a collective delusional belief about certain topics at the university.

job_title: Junior Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: there was ok healthcare and overhead structure. there were good hours and an excellent location in terms of commuting.
cons: there were no meals included nor any other such perks, such as year end bonus or the like. some of my coworkers were not nice people.

job_title: Admissions Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The job isn't challenging, just a lot of scanning applications of prospective students. The job looks good on a resume and is a nice way to get work experience.
cons: The work can become very repetitive and monotonous. Most students don't stay past a semester or two because of the boring work environment.

review_title: I have stayed at NYU for the personal flexibility.
job_title: Contract Officer in New York, NY
pros: NYU' greatest pros are the flexibility and benefits it offers its employees. Lots of vacation and sick time, and retirement benefits make this a great place to work.
cons: Decentralization makes navigating NYU unduly difficult.  Each school has its own administrative infrastructure so there is quite a bit of duplication and a real lack of consistency.

job_title: Peer Tutor in New York, NY
pros: Free to schedule one on one tutoring hours on your own, just had to log it in time sheet.
cons: Nothing really, more than min wage pay. Pay would increase based on seniority. Basically you can expect to make $11 as a sophmore student who is peer tutoring, but one dollar more per year thereafter.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: NYU Silver is in the middle of Greenwich Village, so the students are pretty unparalleled re: diversity.
cons:
The school has undergone a lot of changes and many of the tenured faculty are cliquey, back-biting and totally divorced from and disrespectful toward the students and the administrative staff.  

Adjuncts have no office space and are paid poorly considering the school's location and private university status.

review_title: Positive experience, however depends on your specific team/department
job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: lots of room for movement internally in different departments, tuition remission
cons: your specific team can very much affect your experience - it's a very big institution (largest private employer in city of NY) with a lot of dispersed teams and departments. Lots of opportunities, but you have to seek them and look after yourself.

job_title: Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The team working with you in Resource Center (R(C)As and RHRM) are really nice and helpful (although this depends on the building you’re working in)! It is a great community to work with and the residents soon start to recognize you and spring up conversations, making it an all around pleasant experience.
cons: Depending on your building, you probably won’t get a lot of hours each week.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I am a graduate student and get paid while finishing my PHD.  That's the reason why I am here.
cons: My advisor is not very fair and only cares about what can make his reputation within the profession a lot better.

job_title: Web Developer in New York, NY
pros: Good for people who has family. Work schedule is very stable. Great tuition remission and other benefit. People are very friendly and easy going. Walking distant to Washington Square Park which can be great in the summer.
cons: Don't expect to get as good pay as in private sector. Some people has been worked there for many years and promotion sometimes is rather difficult.

review_title: Great place to work at Data Services!
job_title: Quant Data Analysis Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Flexible work hours, great supervisors and colleagues, opportunities to learn advanced courses, collaborative culture, relatively good salary as opposed to other on-campus jobs.
cons: It's a better environment for self-starters-- You have to take initiatives to learn, otherwise you would probably spend a lot of time doing job-irrelevant stuff during free time at work.

review_title: NYU is a very hierarchical organization, highly bureaucratic, but very well resourced.
job_title: Part Time Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Well resources, well-renowned, AWESOME benefits package.  Over all employees are inundated with great resources and professional development.
cons: Bureaucratic, impersonal, hierarchical. Space is an eternal issues. Office are small, unattractive looking and will probably be shuffled around the university between years because of the constant building and expanding.

job_title: Senior Marketing Associate / Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Flexible schedules
Easy to get to work
Fun people
Tons of new things to learn
cons:
Insufferable people may be an issue. If you're not a people person then this is not the job for you. 
Consider the scheduling of training days in advance as they usually will coincide with other club activities

job_title: S M A R T Aide in New York, NY
pros: The supervising staff at the Academic Resource Center is extremely friendly and helpful, and they seem to genuinely appreciate student staff members
cons: The Academic Resource Center sees a lot of traffic, and it can be stressful to deal with so many people at once

job_title: Program Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Professionalism, good benefits, great atmosphere, easily can take time off, easy going management, diversity and love coming to work everyday.
cons: No career advancement opportunities because of the size of the department. Everyone who has been here has worked here 20+ years so they obviously have not moved up within their perspective positions.

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: This school offers great benefits and there's a lot of opportunity to move to other areas.  I would recommend working here as a stepping stone in your career.
cons: The school is very big and extremely bureaucratic.  They keep staff who don't perform due to union rules which creates a divide between management and staff.

review_title: Research Assistant at NYU Neuroscience Institute
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: The resources are incredible. Scientific possibilities are far reaching to say the least. The facilities at the new institute are impeccable. All staff and scientists are humble, friendly, and easy to work with.
cons: Some of the administrative aspects take longer than usual, because NYU is a very large institution.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Its good to work as a TA as you get to be in touch with the previous course and the beneficial is to be a TA of a good course work that helps you enhance your skills with good pay
cons: sometimes hectic, you need to manage both work and your course work. Sacrifice of weekends sometimes to manage your course work along with the job

job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros: Lots lots resources for a PhD student. However, it also depends on the departments. I was in Engineering school, and they have quite wide spectrum of interests.
cons: Stipend system was inconsistent. Sometimes, they missed a few of paychecks. It took a while (~a few months) to get ones.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
- Decent wage
- 90% of Basic Health insurance covered.
- Dental insurance covered
- Flexible work schedule.
- Cool professors.
cons:
- Tuition was not covered
- Housing and accommodation was not covered.

review_title: Still in Startup Mode/School of Professional Studies
job_title: Instructional Designer in New York, NY
pros: Instructional Design/Educational Tech team is great although mostly contract. Some interesting course development projects. Benefits, vacation, and sick time are really great.
cons: Center Leadership is not so great. No vision, no focus, no respect for the ID team. Lots of tedious work, lots of inefficiencies.

job_title: Executive Director in New York, NY
pros: Location, vacation, benefits, some people are good to work with
cons: School's upper management creates a hostile work environment, will make you pay for taking sick/vacation time.  Low morale.  Upper management makes you feel worthless.  Don't go to HR to discuss your problems with management; they don't keep anything you say to them confidential.  Lots of cronyism in management positions.  They don't care about workers: "anyone can be replaced"

job_title: Communications Manager in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful president and some inspiring leaders at the top as well as some very dedicated employees. Great mission.
cons: Little to no oversight of managers, non-existent systems, no proper annual reviews or upward feedback, lots of career employees who are ignorant of and resistant to best practices. Those who just sit tight and stay keep rising to the top despite and those with more potential tend to leave.

job_title: Intern in New York, NY
pros: I was an intern though so work was a little repetitive, however it was more than made up for in the work environment.
cons: Not challenging enough for an intern. Would be great if there was a chance to actually be in charge of certain projects.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Diversity, a lot of career opportunities, high salary, close to family, business center, fashion center, good night life, good business school
cons: traffic, high living expenses, crowded, dirty, intense work. Life is not as relax as western coast. cold in the winter

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Some solid academic programs. NYU has garnered an impressive reputation in select programs in finance, economics, mathematics, and philosophy. But really, 50 years from now do you want to say you went to NYU?
cons: Lots of useless programs with inadequate intensity. So many programs that could be removed and polish the school's reputation as being a 60 thousand dollar party.

job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: NYU offers good benefits, a flexible work/life balance and the opportunity to move around the organization if you play your cards right.
cons: Red tape can be demotivating at times, not a lot of room for development on the administrative side, a lot of bureaucracy and politics which can sometimes be toxic.

job_title: Administrative Aid in New York, NY
pros: Good food in the neighborhood, great urban campus
cons:
Poor leadership, chronically bad bosses, caught some being unprofessional to students. Total lack of support for workers that haven't worked enough hours to enter the Union. 
Collective Bargaining salary schedule is very low, the university uses the schedule as set values for salary not minimum salary.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Jersey City, NJ
pros: good pay, cool environment, chill out work and flexible people. Feels like one is independent to his work whehever he feels
cons: Good eple start searching for more professional and full time jobs, colege is not place to be forever, hence churn is high

review_title: Good place to be a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Good housing (when you can get it), pretty good benefits (if you're on a faculty member's grant; not if you're on your own fellowship grant).
cons: Because postdoc salaries are set by NIH and are standardized across the country, no matter where you live, the salary doesn't go very far in NYC because the cost of living is so high.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It is a friendly academic environment. Working with brilliant professor is a plus. Besides, you can get access to the whole library facilities in New York University.
cons: Teaching undergraduate students when you know half of the class is actually showing up doesn't really motivate me to some extent.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits (Tuition remission for dependents and self). Focus on Work-Life balance. Location.
cons: Promotion possibilities largely depends on school, division, or department. Surprisingly conservative senior management. Lagged behind other major universities as far as LGBT partner benefits.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: I love my coworkers.  Training is decent.  Your work-life balance will depend upon who your managers are.
cons: Your work-life balance will depend upon who your managers are.  I work in an office with a very top-down management style.  It can be very corporate and very anxious.

review_title: Great benefits, little care for your development
job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Incredible benefits, free tuition to most master's programs, generally reasonable hours
cons: Difficult to move up or across departments, little care for your professional development, horrible bureaucracy where decisions are made at a glacial pace, run too much like a large corporate rather than a university

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The professors I work with and the classes I teach for are fantastic, access to all NYU facilities
cons: Huge bureaucracy - I've been a TA for 2 semesters and have yet to get my permanent ID card, the orientation was unrelated to being a TA or anything to do with education, no opportunity for advancement within the University infrastructure

job_title: PhD Student in New York, NY
pros: Compared to other higher education institutions NYU is generous to their graduate students and I am grateful for that.
cons: Although in comparison to other institutions they are 'generous'; they amount of money given to phd students is very limited to live in New York City.

job_title: Administrative Aide II in New York, NY
pros: Tons of opportunities for professional development, good benefits, positive and open-minded work culture.
cons: Not much room for growth for many people. Many people stay stagnant and only receive promotions or raises when they are long overdue. People get very comfortable and do not like changing processes for the better.

job_title: Visual Experience Designer in New York, NY
pros: I work at OGS. Office of Global Services. International people all over the place. It is really well located and you get the change to work with real communities and students. They encourage innovation and new technologies, so you can be really propositive
cons: If you are a student, your time is limited by the time you will spend studying at NYU.

job_title: Web Publisher Student Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Flexible hours, positive work environment, decent pay. Reasonably compelling work, lots of flexibility in what you do. Excellent boss, and you get to study on the job!
cons: Most of your work isn't as exciting as somewhere more exposed to the market. Not exactly boring but also not the most interesting place to work. Also interdepartmental politics are very petty.

review_title: Administrative Aide review; New York University
job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: Great collegial work environment, tuition remission benefits, and generous 401k match and vacation.  Overall very good work / life balance.  Most Administrative Aide positions are unionized which provides job safety and consistency with raises.
cons: highly bureaucratic, lack of promotion or growth opportunity, hesitancy to adapt and streamline processes, reluctancy to change.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: I have not been at NYU as a part-time instructor for long, but so far it's been wonderful. Very welcoming staff and many perks to faculty such as free courses and seminars.
cons: Their intranet, or internal NYU employee and student portal is a bit confusing, and they seem to have way too many portals. Making it hard to navigate.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: NYU attracts people from all different circles and its good for networking and benefits available are quite good
cons: Bureaucracy is very annoying and sometimes NYU just changes contracts on the fly to save their money which is rightfully yours

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in New York, NY
pros:
Great University
Lots of great minds
NYU community came together during Sandy Hurricane.
cons:
My position does not offer room for growth
Incompetent managers

job_title: Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Interesting research going on here, access to amazing lectures, great location, people are decent.
cons: Bureaucracy and lack of political will stymie hard working people from getting their jobs done well. Status quo rules even when it makes bad business sense.

review_title: Great Company, very nice bosses and a great learning experiences.
job_title: Event Staff in New York, NY
pros: Flexible hours, very accommodating to a students schedule. They are also very helpful when it comes to payment and creating the necessary paperwork.
cons: It takes a very long time to hear back from many of the jobs you applied for. There is also not a lot of possibility for a salary increase.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Location is good.The begin of the fifth ave and close to SOHO.  And you have a lot of chance to take some classes you like.
cons: The housing and living expense is high. Maybe it is always like that in big cities. The competition is really fierce.  You have to be ready all the time.

review_title: Terrible environment; departments are pitted against one other; lot of backstabbing and undermining of others.
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are great as are the time off policies.  Great location excluding the fact that NYU is taking over the Village.
cons: Negative, hostile environment.  People are intentionally mean and nasty to others.  This is supposedly  a place that nurtures, cares for, and educate students yet they have no respect for their employees. Employees are treated terribly and exist in a culture of fear.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: the resources from NYU's deal with Abu Dhabi are unbelievable - and there's so much money around the NYU-NYC campus it's hard to believe
cons: so decentralized to be almost completely dysfunctional. No one knows how the tech campus NYU bought in Brooklyn will be integrated

job_title: in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great work environment, Good supervisor and manager. Very flexible and family oriented. Offers benefits such wage worker, credit union, training, dental, eye, medical, 401k, pension as well as sick, personal, and vacations days.
cons: very little room for upward mobility, as well as low base salary and wage increases. Benefit pack does not compensate for the lower base salary.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work in
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- Decent benefits
- Competitive work environment, quite fast-paced; connects well to "real" businesses
- Work on all levels of the hierarchy
- Decent chances of promotion
cons:
- Typical business environment: huge amount of bureaucracy
- Slackness, demotivated staff
- School environment: really slow in months of summer

review_title: Disconnected, Terrible Communication, and Doesn't care about it's administrators
job_title: Program Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, some really incredibly people, always something to do/see/explore
cons: Really feels like the university doesn't care about it's administrators, really poor communication at the university level and at the school level, some people who work there are terrible at their jobs and everyone else around them has to pick up the slack.

review_title: Mostly good, but could definitely be better
job_title: Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: NYU is a great, progressive school and it does feel rewarding working among competent, intelligent colleagues who are committed to furthering knowledge and research in their respective fields.
cons: There is a lot of red tape and bureaucracy to wade through. HR doesn't particularly care about staff morale and the environment can often be negative.

job_title: Assistant Media Planner in New York, NY
pros: I got a paid part-time position in a digital advertising capacity that gave me relevant experience and actually paid decently
cons: The bureaucracy and politics of higher ed institutions do not allow for fast decisions to be made and makes it harder, if not impossible, to adopt of the latest technologies and trends in a fast-changing industry

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros:
You get in touch with a lot of students and great faculty members.
The location is good.
cons:
Some administrators are very narrow-minded, with no vision of innovation.
The salary is really low, compared to what we pay, as students.

job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Flexibility of time; great location to work; relatively calm and stress free environment,
cons: Very bureaucratic system every decision has to go through several steps before you hear back, politics around space as space is extremely limited, academicians have fragile ego's and are very guarded about their work, job responsibilities can get blurred and confusing, promotions take a long time

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: My job is unique so it won't be much help to most people trying to judge job possibilities for themselves.
cons: Rely on grants. Have to raise money constantly, which is a distraction from actually doing work, though it does provide some freeedom.
