review_title: It's what you make of it.
job_title: Counselor in New York, NY
pros: NYU is a great place to work if you take advantage of the location and the University as a whole. Salaries aren't great but you can take classes for professional growth.
cons: Career growth can be difficult.

job_title: Editorial Manager in New York, NY
pros: I was offered more money here than at any other position I've held in magazine publishing. I have a lot of freedom and am encouraged by my boss' willingness to support me.
cons: Every decision has to be made by committee. Too many meetings that don't result in anything.

job_title: Human Research Compliance Director in New York, NY
pros: NYU is a global institution with the potential to transfer to international sites.
cons: For ERA, NYU is about 10 years behind the times.Salary increases do not always keep up with NYC COLA, tuition remission for many courses and programs is not 100%

job_title: Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Excellent facilities, clean and modern-looking office, mostly friendly work atmosphere, occasional meetings.
cons: Some unprofessional employees' behaviors are being tolerated.

job_title: Student Developer in New York, NY
pros: Coworkers are generally helpful and friendly. Work is challenging but not stressful.
cons: All the student employees had to move into two very cramped rooms due to another department moving in.  Student employees were not consulted about this at all.

review_title: Great and inclusive environment, but slow skill growth
job_title: Admissions Counselor in New York, NY
pros: The work place is very inclusive. You will see diversity everywhere. You're also not overworked. You'll almost never be stuck doing work past 5 pm. Tuition remission is a big plus.
cons: You have to work at least a year to benefit from tuition remission. Some parts of the job can be robotic.

job_title: Web Developer in New York, NY
pros: Great group of people, very interesting and challenging work, with lots of responsibility given if you can show that you can do the work.
cons: Pay a bit on the low side. Also there seemed to be a bit of territory holding and fighting between departments, causing some tension in cooperation.

job_title: Realtor in Oroville, CA
pros: This job has great pay, and it would be an honor if I could work as a realtor some day. It would be much appreciated.
cons: I think that one of the worst things about this kind of job, is being away from your family. I can only imagine what these employers go through.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: I love the way that NYU takes advantage of its location in NYC, and the way it is building the first Global Network University. I just traveled around the world on a research trip, and it was wonderful to have a home in Abu Dhabi and another in Shanghai.
cons: we are perpetually short of space

job_title: General Engineering Teaching Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Flexible hours and counts as federal work study. Coworkers are friendly, and the job is rewarding.
cons: Maximum of 20 hours per week. Do not get paid overtime or given benefits. Paychecks are occassionally delayed because of nyu system problems.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: The greatest experience to mold minds to see clearly, think deeply, read voraciously and become an expert in their field of expertise and to become a mensch.
cons: NY is very cold in the winter and attitudes aren't always pleasant.  Mass transportation is sometimes uncomfortable.  The current Mayor is over the top politically liberal.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: They are really good at working around everyone's class schedule. In addition if you have a hard paper or exam you need to study for you can almost always get a day off to study. Provided you don't do it too often.
cons: The work can be very repetitive and boring.

job_title: Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I loved working here from the very beginning. Even from the job interview, it was like I was hanging out with a friend. There's usually something to do, but I have had time to myself to work on homework or things like that.
cons: Nothing, everything here was great! I enjoyed all my time here.

job_title: IT Support Analyst in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Fair and knowledgable bosses. When there's a time conflict with classes, they understand the student's priorities, and are willing to accommodate.
cons: No bad experiences or scenarios come to mind

job_title: Global Ambassador in Brooklyn, NY
pros: I work for the Graduate Admissions Office and is a great place to work. Everybody is very friendly and helpful. You make friends and bosses are really chill. Event very often, lots of fun and lots of interaction with prospective and new students.
cons: You can't work full time, being and international student.

review_title: Great starting job, growth path non-linear
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
NYU admin roles pay really well starting
You get tuition remission to get an NYU masters at a very reduced price
Working with students can be really exciting and fulfilling
cons:
Employee culture gets overshadowed by NYU building for student culture
Growth in NYU as an admin usually involves pivoting to other departments and schools

job_title: Graduate Student Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- flexible work hours to work with your school schedule
- helpful team with years of experience
- steep learning curve
- normally can try to make the job apply to your major
cons:
- HR can take a long time to process payments
- lots of paperwork for international students to sign up that is not well explained

review_title: Work-Study job while enrolled at NYU
job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Friendly staff and supervisor, work is not very challenging, so doesn't distract from classes. New Cooper Square location is nice.
cons: Work is not challenging; can be dull and repetitive. Work-study jobs pay a few cents above minimum wage. Lots of international students working who do not speak good English.

job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: The only reason I liked working here is that I got to leave promptly at 5pm. If anything were enjoyable about this job, it wouldn't have been necessary to leave on-the-dot every day.
cons: Horrible HR, horrible administration, no system in place to discipline horrible managers, terrible treatment to students who pay a ton of money to attend.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Like any university environment, there is an enormous amount of flexibility and plenty of time to do whatever else you need to do as a student while also working
cons: I frequently work more than the allotted 20 hours per week for my position and over time isn't really something I can easily get paid for

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Very understanding in regards to student schedule. I was able to get time off when there was a large influx in course work or exams.
cons: Not many. There was some tension in the administration but those issues were well above the student level.

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The staff are friendly, there's a lot of down-time so students can study/work on homework, the work itself isn't difficult at all, and there's always free food available. The employee's work schedule is easily negotiable as well.
cons: The daily tasks at work can get very repetitive.

job_title: Resident Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The department of Residential Life and Housing Services is very supportive. As a student staff you get a lot of benefits.
cons: Since the compensation is very attractive, the application process is very competitive. Connections sometimes trump qualifications.

job_title: Information Technology in New York, NY
pros: Great if you have a good boss. Not much work and when its dead you can spend the time studying.
cons: Everything is very structural so dont expect things to be done fast

review_title: Huge learning experience. Tough and competitive environment
job_title: in Garden City, NY
pros: Very big reputation, great working with educated stimulating people, cosmopolitan area, huge learning experience
cons: Some people very self serving, self promoting, arrogant.  Must have strong self esteem to work w some people!

review_title: Too many hats dealing ewith tooo many fools
job_title: Technical Administrator in New York, NY
pros: you can slack off a lot if you are lazy
cons: See above. Lots of people do this, particularly tech staff

job_title: Web Developer in New York, NY
pros:
Tuition remission is a giant savings, if you plan on taking classes. First undergrad degree is essentially free.
Stable hours - none of the 60 hour work week stuff. 
I feel I can make an impact on our services.
cons: Pay is a bit low, while personal contribution to health care plan seems high.

job_title: Adjunct Professor Production Supervision in New York, NY
pros: Excellent colleagues, superb students, great staff.
cons: Salary is too low for the position.

job_title: IT ASSISTANT in New York, NY
pros: Work study is A+++; if you have it USE IT. Flexible hours, the bosses don't give you any work basically, and it's ON CAMPUS.
cons: There's a chance they WILL take away work study from you. It has happened to me. So use it while you can.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Friendly staff and great location. I felt like I was a respected member of the team for the most part.
cons: Cons are low pay, not much room for growth. My manager micromanaged more that I'd typically prefer.

job_title: Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Good labs, solid research, cool professors. Location is awesome, they help out with housing, etc., it definitely has great perks.
cons: Bureaucracy can be frustrating at times, lots of moving parts involved. Get to know the right people and you'll get anything you need.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The staff is awesome and the bosses are always super nice and understanding, if you get a good class, the job can be a great experience.
cons: You can't always get a lot of hours and the pay is usually meager. I make my own monthly rent in about a year of working there.

review_title: Wonderful place to grow your career and enhance your education
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Nutley, NJ
pros:
Benefits - generous vacation days, sick days, bonding leave, and tuition remission
Colleagues
intellectually stimulating environment
flextime/telecommuting policy
cons:
Systems that do not work together.
Redundant bureaucracy with central office which create barriers to task progress (Accounts Payable, Payroll, Purchasing)
Outdated HR candidate application software.

review_title: NYU Student Worker is a Solid Position
job_title: Tech Manager in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
Take my words with a grain of salt since I am just a student worker not an actual full-time employee
-Flexible Hours
-As a student worker I study and work by managing my time
-Great connections to other students
cons: -Can be hard applying to other jobs while being a student worker

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
The Physics department only requires two years of teaching if you can secure funding for later years.
Exciting research opportunities in Soft Matter Physics, Cosmology, Observational Astronomy and Theoretical Astrophysics.
cons:
Very little guidance given to the graduate student outside of their advisor.
Little cohesiveness between disciplines.
Graduate course selection is limited outside of theoretical cosmology.

job_title: Department Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: NYU provides many excellent benefits to it's full-time employees and the culture is a supportive and encouraging one.
cons: As with any large employer, there are layers of bureaucracy that can be difficult to maneuver, but overall it is not in any way stifling

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: What can I say? It is a good place to work at. Right in the heart of NYC. Step outside of your lab and you are at the center of the world. Pay was better than most places.
cons: Sometimes it can get bureaucratic. But once you figured things out you should be fine.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer of Writing in New York, NY
pros: I was an adjunct writing professor for international graduate students at NYU. The pay is a few dollars more an hour than that of other NYC universities.
cons: Classes took place in a crowded midtown building. The atmosphere was rushed, anonymous and cold. They expected a lot of work that was unpaid -- meetings, conferences, and obviously, prep and correcting papers. (Though to be fair, this is true of all adjuncts everywhere). However the administration was very demanding and abrupt. Not worth it.

review_title: Great place to do a postdoc in biology
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
State of the are resources available for biology research. 
Good benefits package including health, dental, vision, and up to 10% matching contributions to retirement savings plan.
cons: Institutional bureaucracy is cumbersome.  There is not a great community of postdocs, networking opportunities, or resources such as career development.

review_title: a nice place to study and work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: best location, friendly environment and the salary is not bad. students can get jobs like grader, TA and RA to pay for their living expenses.
cons: a little crowded, there are always too many people around. Career service for PhD student is not satisfactory.

job_title: Resident Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Room & Board, Single Room, trainings in many fields, opportunities, relationships, benefits
cons: Easily disposable, don't get as much vocation as students, very time consuming, on call 24/7, always being watched, work and house is the same place

review_title: Stable Work // Growth Difficult to Impossible
job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: Stable; hours are steady; union; planned raises; employer name recognition; taxes are deducted; good insurance; academic environment; location; some downtime for working on your own projects
cons: stagnant; growth is difficult; high turnover in clerical jobs; get stuck in clerical positions; administrators are not respected; promotion of poor mid-level employees

job_title: Resident Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Room and board, support from pro-staff, great community with staff, fun on programs!, personal development!
cons: TIME commitment is a lot! You are never off duty because you live where you work!

job_title: PhD Student in Brooklyn, NY
pros: It is one of the top schools in usa computer science and engineering. It offers cyber security courses as well as basic computer science. Some profs are so successful in their fields.
cons: Many adjunct profs are are not well qualified. Also, some masters courses are for money making, the quality is low for them.

review_title: Have tough skin to work here
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Niece place to work if you have tough skin, Doctors and upper management don’t have an idea about AV.
cons: Upper management doesn’t have a clue on how to manage teams

review_title: Comfortable place to work, but no room for growth
job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros:
- Low stress, low pressure the vast majority of the time
- Great educational and health benefits
cons:
- Extremely rigid hierarchy, no room for growth
- People who are ambitious and want to learn and grow will eventually get fed up with the complete inertia of the environment and leave

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: It is a very stable place of employment (especially if you are under a union contract). The environment is a great working environment, I think that depends on your department, however. But I like it.
cons: Not much cons I do not think. I cannot think of any at the moment.

job_title: Assistant Professor/Faculty Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment, subsidized housing on campus, great colleagues and students, reasonable course loads (2 courses per semester). The whole experience was really positive.
cons: My position was a temporary position. It was not a tenure track position unlike a regular assistant professorship. It could only last for three years. Not renewable.

review_title: Great administrative staff who care about education
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Smart intelligent co-workers who care about education and those providing it
cons: As administrative support staff, it is hard getting faculty on the same page. Their job is to educate, our job is to support and make their life easier on an administrative standpoint, bump heads a lot

job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: -Tuition remission opportunities for you and your family.
cons:
-Poor treatment from management. 
-Ineffective administrators who unfairly defer their responsibilities.
-Bureaucratic system that repeatedly fails to accomplish tasks.
-Small, but highly vindictive human resources department
-Growth opportunities located outside of Tisch, not within. 
-Inappropriate work environment. 
-Consistent budget crises that have given way to cutting positions. Many departments are short-staffed as a result.
-Professors are disrespectful and have more say in the run of the school than management.

review_title: It is a great place to work. Nice environment, lay-back smart people and intellectually stimulation
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Nice location with great history, cultural, food scenes. Great resources to work like the supercomputer clusters and library data bases. Great benefit and tuition remission ,
cons: Pay is not competitive

job_title: Yard in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Good well spoken nice mannered people who work hard all of the time,  a nice group of people to be around for the duration of your day.
cons: There were many challenges including those of counting money,  organising staff,  produce orders,  the timing of many daily tasks were off.

job_title: Post-Production Technician in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great people to work with and a pleasant work environment. Great benefits and are great to military reservist.
cons: Have late hrs and because its a union position there is no where for me to get promoted in my unit.

job_title: Concierge in New York, NY
pros: Plenty of opportunity and room for growth. There is always someone w
cons: It may take a little while to get where you are going but you will get there

job_title: Department Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission is awesome! It allows you to take classes and get an education at the institution you work for. Very rewarding.
cons: With such an old institution, sometimes it can be hard to set change in motion. It can take a while for new things to get up and off the ground.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY
pros: My experience was generally positive. I enjoyed working with students. There was a lot of freedom in terms of curriculum design.
cons: Employment period was capped at 2 years. From my understanding, this was because NYU did not want to pay benefits and would have to if employment lasted longer than 2 years.

job_title: Assistant Dean in New York, NY
pros: NYU Stern was an incredible place to work - opportunities for professional growth and development, collaborative team culture and total commitment to student success and experience.
cons: The university can be a bit silo'd with each school operating independently.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The great thing about working at NYU is that it's a recognizable name that any one else in higher education has heard of and of course the location.
cons: The School of Continuing and Professional Studies is a horribly managed division of the university with poor management from the top to bottom.  Incredibly high turn over over the past few years has resulted in management from top to bottom that is relatively inexperienced and has no internal support.

review_title: Working Part time at Steinhardt! Best on-campus job experience ever!
job_title: Computer Technician in New York, NY
pros: Amazing people. Great work ethic. Scope to learn a lot.
cons: Too many people. Bad building infrastructure.

review_title: Review for student or temporary positions
job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
> The co workers are  usually very nice and understanding
> Pay is relatively good
> Not much micro managing
cons:
> A lot of bureaucracy
> Not much benefits
> If you work for operations, you are expected on work on most snow days

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits such a tuition remission. Vacation due to school closures which is great. To get to see students become professionals
cons: Not enough quality within front line staff . Students need to understand that they are not entitled to get what they want anytime

job_title: Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The location of the university is definitely one of the best: right at the heart of the big apple. Easy traffic and more exposure to opportunities
cons: Busy traffic and noisy campus. I would not call it a good place for scientific research. Expensive rent and everything. Chemistry department not so great.

job_title: in Philadelphia, PA
pros: NYU matches $10 for every $5 you contribute toward retirement plan.  If you have kids, they can attend NYU for free if they can get in.
cons: New administration looking to cut costs wherever they can since it is known to be one of the most expensive schools in the country.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great Environment, Supportive staff. The supervisor is very supportive of newly grad students and help them learn and let them contribute at their own pace.
cons: There are not any cons and the work environment is pretty good and balanced. So there are no cons that are there for me.

review_title: Good chance for engaging in research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Allowed for a great start to my résumé during my Master's academic career
cons:
Some of the lab work (depending on the project) can be quite boring
Some professors can be overbearing

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: NYU is a supportive and flexible place to work. For those who want to continue their education, employees can attend most undergraduate and graduate programs for free.
cons: Some systems (like their vendor payment systems) are archaic and difficult to use. The pay, like in any non-profit setting, is low.

job_title: Student Budget in New York, NY
pros: Supervisors understand that you need scheduling flexibility because of the nature of the job, they give you time off for finals and other tests.
cons: Low pay, and sometimes very long hours, there is little room to grow, and since 2009 they don't give raises, repetitive.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Total work timings and the pay are really good
Wide exposure
We get to learn while we teach
cons: The only Cons I could think of is probably the timings. We have to manage and adjust according to other Teaching Assistants and all the seniors get the priority leaving juniors very little choice.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Leaves some time to do homework as a student and the staff is usually friendly and accommodating.
Free food is served sometimes.
cons: Schedules can be very inconvenient and at certain parts of the semester becomes a lot of work compared to what you are paid for, especially at minimum wage.

job_title: MS Student, Global Affairs in New York, NY
pros: The NYU School of Professional Studies has an excellent global affairs program. Professors are very engaging and invested in their students.
cons: NYU is very expensive to attend. Library spaces are also quite overcrowded.

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: One of the most prestigious universities in the country, a lot of professional development opportunities, autonomy to develop programs, great resources, great students.
cons: No room for professional growth (promotions), very political system based on favoritism.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
-- Very good HR department ready to help
-- Good pay for a graduate research assistant
-- Good balance for professional/social life
-- A friendly community that make you feel like NYU is home
cons: None as I observed as a part-time researcher.

job_title: Tutor in New York, NY
pros: Solid part time job. Nothing great about it. Nothing bad. Will say it was one of my easier part time jobs ever.
cons: It got a little annoying when students didn’t bother to study but that’s what tutoring is for. Also, people expected you to do their homework for them.

review_title: Working for a private University in Manhattan.
job_title: Administrative Aide in New York, NY
pros: Great environment, bustling and engaging. Easy atmosphere but professional. Lots of room for growth and learning.

review_title: Great Place to work or be a student

review_title: It is a good experience to work and study here
